Not quite, but the servers are down for the popular college football game. And it's added to the early problems players have found in the first days of the game's release.\n\nThe College Football 25 servers were down at 6 a.m. ET Wednesday, July 17 for maintenance. The Orlando-based company announced the move the previous night.\n\nDown Detector, which tracks outages and service errors, showed a spike in reports of EA outages at 7 a.m., and while that has died down, reported issues spiked again before 10:30 a.m.\n\nCollege Football 25 is the first new college football video game since NCAA Football 14 more than a decade ago. As of 11 a.m., the College Football 25 server was the only one reported to be down.\n\nEA unable to connect: How can I play College Football 25?\n\nEA Help gave tips for signing into your EA account before starting Dynasty Mode. Press R2 on the PS5 or RT on the Xbox Series X|S to sign in.\n\nUsers on Reddit suggest disabling the internet connection to disconnect from online play. The modes apparently still work offline.\n\nHowever, as many frustrated users wrote on social media, one of the top draws of the game was the ability to play against your friends and other college football fans. So EA's early struggles remain frustrating.\n\nCollege Football 25 release date: When is the game out?\n\nEA Sports College Football 25 is available to play now if you preordered. It is not available for PC, PS4 and Xbox One.\n\nCollege Football 25 price: How much does the game cost?\n\nThe standard version of the game is $69.99. {"uri": "2024-07-425167729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-17", "time": "18:48:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-17T18:48:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-17T18:30:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://gamerant.com/college-football-25-faq-frequently-asked-questions/", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25 Burning Questions", "body": "College Football 25 Experiencing Server Issues Ahead of Full Release\n\nAfter a decade-long hiatus, EA Sports has finally returned to the world of college football, much to the delight of the sport's many fans. It may not have NCAA in the title anymore, but based on early showings, it seems fair to say that EA Sports College Football 25 is every bit as enjoyable as its licensed predecessors, offering up a ton of different game modes and some of the best visuals to ever grace an American football game.\n\nRelated\n\nCollege Football 25: Road To Glory - Which Journey Should You Choose?\n\nBefore embarking on their player career in EA Sports College Football 25, players should familiarize themselves with the differences in journey types.\n\nHowever, with even the cheapest version of the game priced at $70, potential buyers may want to do their research before deciding whether or not to part with their hard-earned cash. Others may just have questions about some of the game's features and core mechanics. The following guide will aim to answer all of the most frequently asked questions about EA Sports College Football 25, including those concerning crossplay and local co-op support.\n\nEA Sports College Football 25 Frequently Asked Questions\n\nClose\n\nWhich Platforms is College Football 25 Available on?\n\nCollege Football 25 is available on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S.\n\nWill College Football 25 be Coming to PS4 and Xbox One?\n\nAs of the time of writing, EA doesn't appear to be planning to bring the game to last-gen consoles.\n\nDoes College Football 25 Support Crossplay?\n\nYes. College Football 25 supports crossplay. Players can learn how it all works by visiting EA's Cross-Play FAQ.\n\nDoes College Football 25 Support Local Multiplayer?\n\nCollege Football 25 allows up to four people to play together locally, although, just like in the game's online multiplayer mode, only two players will be able to control a single team.\n\nWhat Time Will College Football 25 be Released?\n\nCollege Football 25 will be released at midnight EDT on July 19.\n\nHow Can I Play College Football 25 Early?\n\nThose who pre-order the Deluxe version of the game or MVP bundle will be able to start playing the game three days earlier than everybody else. The early access period begins at 4 pm EDT on July 15.\n\nCan I Preload College Football 25?\n\nYes. Those who pre-order College Football 25 will be able to start preloading the game 48 hours before release.\n\nHow Big is College Football 25? (College Football 25 File Size)\n\nThe PS5 version of College Football 25 that's available to early access players is 27.07 GB, although this may change if there's a Day 1 patch.\n\nWhich Version of College Football 25 Should I Buy?\n\nThose who just want the basic experience should go with Standard, while anyone who wants early access or sinking a lot of time into the game's Ultimate Team game mode should go with Deluxe. The MVP Bundle may prove appealing to those who plan on picking up Madden 25, as it includes the Deluxe versions of both games for just $50 more.\n\nWill College Football 25 be on Game Pass and PlayStation Plus?\n\nNo. As of the time of writing, there is nothing to suggest that College Football 25 will be coming to Game Pass or PlayStation Plus. However, EA Play subscribers can try out the game for up to ten hours, with a one-month subscription coming in at $5.99. Xbox Game Pass Ultimate also includes EA Play, so Ultimate subscribers can take advantage of this free ten-hour trial as well as a ten percent discount on the full release.\n\nCan I Transfer My Custom Character Over to Madden 25?\n\nYes. After their Road to Glory character retires from college football, players will have the option of transferring them over to Madden 25. It's worth noting that players will need to be connected to the EA servers for this to work.\n\nHow Many Teams Are There in College Football 25?\n\nThere are 134 teams in College Football 25, making it one of the most comprehensive and content-rich college football games ever made.\n\nEA Sports College Football 25\n\nDeveloper(s) EA Orlando\n\nPublisher(s) EA\n\nPlatform(s) PS5 , Xbox Series X , Xbox Series S\n\nReleased July 19, 2024\n\nMore\n\nCollege Football 25 Top 100 Players Revealed\n\nAhead of its July 16 launch, EA Sports reveals the 100 athletes in College Football 25 with the {"uri": "8234114362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:32:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:32:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/19/ea-sports-college-football-25s-100-version-paid-off-for-ea-with-2-2m-early-access-players/", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25's $100 version paid off for EA, with 2.2M early access players", "body": "Electronic Arts' revival of its college football series is already off to an incredibly impressive start. The publisher announced Friday that EA Sports College Football 25, which officially launched Friday, has had more than 2.8 million players, 2.2 million of whom paid to play the sports sim in early access.\n\nThe $99.99 Deluxe Edition of EA Sports College Football 25 offered three days' worth of early access, which led to a massive install base well before the game officially launched. EA said in a news release that an additional 600,000 players got their hands on College Football 25 through EA Play, which offers an early trial version of certain Electronic Arts titles.\n\nIn addition to the deluxe stand-alone version of College Football 25, EA is also selling a $149.99 MVP Bundle that includes the deluxe editions of EA Sports College Football 25 and Madden NFL 25, as well as other in-game perks like virtual currencies. That's an attractive offer for football fans, who would have spent about $140 anyway if they bought those games separately.\n\nOn Tuesday, when the early access period for EA Sports College Football 25 began, in-game statistics showed that more than 700,000 players were online concurrently. On Friday, hours after the game officially launched, concurrent player counts were around 550,000.\n\nAccording to data from research firm Circana (formerly NPD), EA Sports College Football 25 ranked No. 3 in U.S. daily active users on Xbox (behind Call of Duty HQ and Fortnite), and No. 4 on PlayStation 5 (behind COD, Fortnite, and Grand Theft Auto 5), during its early access period, according to executive director and video game industry adviser Mat Piscatella.\n\nAnticipation for EA Sports College Football 25 has been high, naturally, since Electronic Arts hasn't released a college football game since 2013, when it launched NCAA Football 14.\n\nFortunately for fans of college football video games, EA's return to the space has been not just commercially successful, but critically as well. Polygon's review, from critic Matt Brown, says EA Sports College Football 25 was \"worth the wait.\"\n\n\"[EA Sports College Football 25] is also very clearly a labor of love from developers who deeply care about college football and college football culture,\" Brown wrote. \"It's a testament to what is possible with sports games when teams have longer than a few months to crank out AAA titles. And if this is the foundation for future college football games, then the series is in a very, very good place.\"\n\nEA Sports College Football 25 is available now on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series {"uri": "2024-07-427377769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:20:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:20:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.recordherald.com/2024/07/19/ea-sports-college-football-25-among-most-anticipated-sports-video-games-in-history-hits-the-market/", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25, among most anticipated sports video games in history, hits the market", "body": "This combo of images provided by EA Sports, shows the video game covers for the new standard edition College Football 25, left, and Deluxe Edition College Football 25, featuring Texas' Quinn Ewers, Colorado's Travis Hunter, and Michigan's Donovan Edwards. EA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play it. (EA Sports via AP, File)\n\nEA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play.\n\nThe game officially launched Friday, with EA Sports increasing its server capacity ahead of time to handle the crush. More than 2.2 million people had already played the game before launch during an early-access period.\n\n\"To say we've been blown away by the excitement, energy and anticipation around College Football 25 over the past few months would be an understatement,\" EA Sports said in a blog post this week. \"Just like you, our team has had July 19 circled for months as the culmination of so much work and dedication to build this game, and the chance to see it in players' hands for the first time.\"\n\nEA Sports' college football games used to be released annually, a cultural icon in American sports for much of the franchise's existence. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. The video-game developer offered Bowl Subdivision players a minimum of $600 and a copy of the game to have their likeness included in it. More than 11,000 players accepted offers.\n\nEA Sports has said its goal for the game was \"to feel like a love letter to college football and its fans.\"\n\nUCLA, Mississippi State, San Diego State and Colorado were among the schools hosting College Football 25 events this week. Across social platforms, athletes such as LeBron James, Tim Tebow and Michael Vick -- even comedians Shane Gillis and Dan Soder -- were live-streaming head-to-head matches in the game.\n\nMichigan running back Donovan Edwards, one of the cover athletes, said in May some of the best moments of his childhood involved playing EA Sports college football with his best friend.\n\n\"Just for it to be back, as well as to be on the cover of it, it's an awesome feeling,\" he said.\n\nThe game's other standard-edition cover athletes are Texas quarterback Quinn Ewers and Colorado two-way player Travis Hunter. The deluxe edition features the backs of numerous players in a stadium tunnel, including Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe, Georgia quarterback Carson Beck and Ohio State running back Quinshon Judkins.\n\nEA Sports' college football franchise dates to the 1990s. It grew in popularity in the early 2000s as gaming systems became more advanced, allowing for revolutionary game modes such as the popular Race for the Heisman create-a-player that was introduced in NCAA Football 06.\n\nThat edition also featured historic teams, including the 1992 Alabama squad that Clemson coach Dabo Swinney played on.\n\n\"Sleeping on me a little bit,\" Swinney joked about the 70 overall rating for his player, \"WR No. 88,\" which did, however, have a 91 speed rating. \"They must have my going down the Hill speed. And even though the highly anticipated sports game has only been out for less than 24 hours, it's already one of the biggest games of the year.\n\nPre-order EA College Football 25: Amazon | Best Buy | GameStop\n\nIn case you didn't know, the last major college football game developed by EA, NCAA Football 14, was released in 2013, over a decade ago. In that time, players have used mods and hacks to keep the aging Xbox 360/PS3-era soccer sim up to date with the real world. But now, after more than a decade of serving its community, NCAA-14 can rest as EA College Football 25 is out and already wildly popular.\n\nTechnically, EA College Football 25 won't launch until July 19th. But like so many publishers, EA is holding the game hostage unless you pay a ransom to play three days early. It's a dirty move, but it hasn't stopped the new sports title from exploding online. According to multiple reports on Twitter, College Football 25 at one point i had more than 660,000 players online simultaneously. Later in the evening it appears that the new game reaches 713,974 online players.\n\nTo put that number in perspective, it's far better than Helldivers 2, which reached a player count of around 485,000 shortly after its launch. It is also more than The first descendantS 264,000 players earlier this month. And that number of players is just a stone's throw away from Baldurspoort 3's peak of 875,000 on Steam last year. In fact, that number would be 713,000 College Football 25 the second biggest game on Steam in the last 48 hours, only Counter Strike 2.\n\nAll of those numbers are impressive on their own, but they're even more impressive when you consider that the game is only available to people who pre-ordered the game. expensive $90 version of College Football 25. Additionally, this game is only available on Xbox Series X/S and PS5, with no previous-gen consoles or Switch versions available, and no Steam or PC port.\n\nIt also seems that EA College Football 25 leads to increased console sales, with more Xbox Series S consoles reportedly sold in the last 24 hours than in any other period outside of the 2020 launch. There is also evidence that the Xbox Series S is selling like hotcakes at Walmart.\n\nI expect this game to only get bigger once it's available to everyone on July 19th. Circana games analyst Mat Piscattela predicts That College Football 25 is set to be in the top 20 best-selling games of 2024, and suggests it could even land in the top 10. {"uri": "8232928736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:06:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:06:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:05:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jul/18/ea-sports-college-football-25-among-most-anticipat/", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25, among most anticipated sports video games in history, hits the market", "body": "EA Sports via AP, file\n\nThis combo of images provided by EA Sports, shows the video game covers for the new standard edition College Football 25, left, and Deluxe Edition College Football 25, featuring Texas' Quinn Ewers, Colorado's Travis Hunter, and Michigan's Donovan Edwards. EA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play it.\n\nBy Ryan Kryska, Associated Press\n\nThursday, July 18, 2024 | 10:50 p.m.\n\nEA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play.\n\nThe game officially launched Friday, with EA Sports increasing its server capacity during early access to handle the crush.\n\n\"To say we've been blown away by the excitement, energy and anticipation around College Football 25 over the past few months would be an understatement,\" EA Sports said in a blog post this week. \"Just like you, our team has had July 19 circled for months as the culmination of so much work and dedication to build this game, and the chance to see it in players' hands for the first time.\"\n\nEA Sports' college football games used to be released annually, a cultural icon in American sports for much of the franchise's existence. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. The video-game developer offered Bowl Subdivision players a minimum of $600 and a copy of the game to have their likeness included in it. More than 11,000 players accepted offers.\n\nEA Sports has said its goal for the game was \"to feel like a love letter to college football and its fans.\"\n\nSan Diego State and Colorado were among the schools hosting College Football 25 events this week. Across social platforms, athletes such as LeBron James, Tim Tebow and Michael Vick -- even comedians Shane Gillis and Dan Soder -- were live-streaming head-to-head matches in the game.\n\nMichigan running back Donovan Edwards, one of the cover athletes, said in May some of the best moments of his childhood involved playing EA Sports college football with his best friend.\n\n\"Just for it to be back, as well as to be on the cover of it, it's an awesome feeling,\" he said.\n\nThe game's other standard-edition cover athletes are Texas quarterback Quinn Ewers and Colorado two-way player Travis Hunter. The deluxe edition features the backs of numerous players in a stadium tunnel, including Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe, Georgia quarterback Carson Beck and Ohio State running back Quinshon Judkins.\n\nEA Sports' college football franchise dates to the 1990s. It grew in popularity in the early 2000s as gaming systems became more advanced, allowing for revolutionary game modes such as the popular Race for the Heisman create-a-player that was introduced in NCAA Football 06.\n\nThat edition also featured historic teams, including the 1992 Alabama squad that Clemson coach Dabo Swinney played on.\n\n\"Sleeping on me a little bit,\" Swinney joked about the 70 overall rating for his player, \"WR No. 88,\" which did, however, have a 91 speed rating. \"They must have my going down the Hill speed. I appreciate the love they gave me on that.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Pete Iacobelli contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas {"uri": "8230937170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "02:32:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T02:32:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T02:31:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/college/mike-vorel-why-return-of-college-football-25-is-a-holiday-for-beloved-video-games/article_85e181d5-99ab-5eef-9b8a-007048cec9d4.html", "title": "Mike Vorel: Why return of 'College Football 25' is a holiday for beloved video game's fans", "body": "Mike Vorel, The Seattle Times\n\nSEATTLE -- In September, a social-media account called \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" began periodically posting one word:\n\n\"No.\"\n\nDays passed, and the \"Nos\" piled up. No. No. No. No. No. But for dedicated college football fans, the wait was even longer.\n\nBefore this week, Electronic Arts' most recent college football video game -- \"NCAA Football 14\" -- had been released on July 9, 2013. The series was then waylaid by legal disputes surrounding player likenesses, pitched into an 11-year purgatory while the sport painstakingly evolved.\n\nOf course, college athletes were finally permitted to be paid for utilizing their name, image and likeness (NIL) in 2021, which allowed EA to compensate the players it profits from. (Players who opted in received $600 ... and, of course, a copy of the game.)\n\nPeople are also reading... Sioux City woman claims $300,000 lottery prize City of Okoboji urges governor to increase releases from Iowa Great Lakes McCook Lake Association president: 'There's really no compensation' for flood losses High school softball: Sioux City West snaps 12-year postseason drought with win Sioux City school district settles student injury lawsuit for $175,000 Woman arrested after chase exceeding 115 mph on I-29 Dan Greenwell to pay $52.7K in attorney fees to former Sioux City superintendent Paul Gausman Hinton man wins $100K in Iowa Lottery scratch game Winnebago family finds meaning in missing, murdered pow wow High school baseball: McCarty leading successful, youthful MOC-FV squad into playoffs Sioux City Career Academy house sells for $150,000 to couple impacted by flooding UPDATED: Okoboji lakes fall below target for lifting boat speeding limits Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 14, 2024 Portion of Outer Drive to temporarily close\n\nAt precisely 1 p.m. Monday, the \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" account posted one more word.\n\nThe wait was over.\n\n\"Yes.\"\n\n\"For a lot of people, this is a holiday,\" Ryan S. Clark, a devotee of the series and NHL writer for ESPN.com, told The Seattle Times on Monday.\n\nIt's a holiday steeped in nostalgia -- in midsummer marathons on prehistoric PlayStations, in triple-option offenses and players lost to time, in critical recruiting battles for fictional five-star safeties, in regional conferences (remember them?) and in-state rivalries.\n\n\"NCAA Football 14\" had 20 predecessors, dating to \"Bill Walsh College Football\" in 1993. It also had a frenzied following, a generation of football fans who developed dynasties -- chiseling national champions out of small-school Cinderellas.\n\n\"For me it was really cool, because I got to see really good teams and players that in 1998, in Minneapolis, I wasn't ever going to see play until the bowl game,\" said Dave Southorn, 42, who later covered Boise State football for The Idaho Statesman and The Athletic. \"You got this really good view of the college football landscape through that game.\n\n\"That really helped me, to be frank, as I was figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. I was like, 'Oh, this is cool.' I knew things that others didn't. Everyone was talking about Michigan or whoever. I was like, 'Have you heard of Tulane?' \"\n\nClark, likewise, celebrated the annual summer release with a weeklong marathon, as he and a friend staged a sport-wide tournament (modeled after the UEFA Champions League in European soccer) to establish supremacy.\n\n\"We did our own statistical tracking [of games],\" said Clark, 39, who traces the tournament to his high-school years in Florida from 1998 to 2002. \"We were absolute nerds about it, and we totally own it. We absolutely own it.\"\n\nConcluded Clark, who lives in Seattle: \"This is what we would do from 4 o'clock in the afternoon to 2 o'clock in the morning every day for a week.\"\n\nDecades later, the arrival of \"EA Sports College Football 25\" has attracted a similar response, flooding social-media feeds with flea flickers and stadium shots and shaking student sections. As 247Sports college football reporter and podcaster Bud Elliott posted Tuesday on X: \"The EA Sports College Football release has completely upstaged media days buzz. Search trends [online] are wild. To the point where talking college football on a college football show instead of talking about the video game is legit bad business.\"\n\nThe business of college football is also reflected in the game, as players must maneuver NIL deals and the transfer portal to retain top talent. An athlete's academics, leadership skills, health, training and brand all must be monitored.\n\nIndeed, a whole lot happened in the 4,025 days between the releases of \"NCAA Football 14\" and \"EA Sports College Football 25.\"\n\nFor the sport, the franchise ... and its fans.\n\n\"The last time this game came out, I wasn't yet engaged,\" Southorn said. \"I've been married for nine years now. That's how long it's been for me.\"\n\nJoked Clark on Monday morning, in a similar situation: \"When 1 o'clock rolls around, my wife understands that it was a great run for our marriage. We had a lot of great years. We put championships in the rafters. But I'm a ghost to her now, and she knows that, God bless her.\"\n\nSouthorn may soon count among the game-playing ghosts. The University of Colorado alum, who now handles content and communications for a hospital system in Idaho, requested off work Friday to reignite a former flame.\n\n\"Daycare is going to come in clutch,\" said the 42-year-old father and Carnation native. \"I'll get up, take [daughter Kennedy] to day care in the morning. Maybe I'll swing by the doughnut shop and grab something, and then just settle in. I'll probably order a pizza or something at lunch, because I don't want to move.\n\n\"I know I'm in a boat with a whole lot of people. When you get to 40ish and you've got kids, you don't have as much time. But I know I'm literally going to find ways to make time. Because we all need something.\"\n\nThis game, for some, is more than a silly aside -- or a time machine to a tournament lasting until 2 a.m. It's not just nostalgia wrapped in new graphics and updated uniforms.\n\nIt's also a referendum on college football's deepening divide, on the parity diluted by super conferences and media-rights money. It's an individual objection -- a place where Army and Akron and Appalachian State can overwhelm Alabama, where Washington State can pummel its former Pac-12 partners into apologetic pieces.\n\nIt's a place where former Notre Dame and Wake Forest quarterback Sam Hartman -- whose Demon Deacons never defeated Clemson in his five seasons as the starter -- can topple the Tigers, 105-34, as they did Tuesday.\n\n\"Just blowing off some steam...\" Hartman posted, along with a screen shot, on social media.\n\nIt's a place where anything is still possible, provided you can play.\n\n\"I think maybe in the back of our lizard brains, you have some control over it now. You can make the Cinderella story happen,\" Southorn said. \"You can build someone up, where realistically it probably wouldn't happen [in the current era of college football] because of NIL and conference affiliation. You can return it to the way it used to be and feel like college football is a little more even or fair. I think that's a big part of it.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that {"uri": "2024-07-425413739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "02:19:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T02:19:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T01:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/sports/college/mike-vorel-why-return-of-college-football-25-is-a-holiday-for-beloved-video-games/article_51f3af5a-dc16-5460-8e44-239720848eea.html", "title": "Mike Vorel: Why return of 'College Football 25' is a holiday for beloved video game's fans", "body": "Mike Vorel, The Seattle Times\n\nSEATTLE -- In September, a social-media account called \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" began periodically posting one word:\n\n\"No.\"\n\nDays passed, and the \"Nos\" piled up. No. No. No. No. No. But for dedicated college football fans, the wait was even longer.\n\nBefore this week, Electronic Arts' most recent college football video game -- \"NCAA Football 14\" -- had been released on July 9, 2013. The series was then waylaid by legal disputes surrounding player likenesses, pitched into an 11-year purgatory while the sport painstakingly evolved.\n\nOf course, college athletes were finally permitted to be paid for utilizing their name, image and likeness (NIL) in 2021, which allowed EA to compensate the players it profits from. (Players who opted in received $600 ... and, of course, a copy of the game.)\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nUPDATE: Cedar Lake woman killed in Monday's storm remembered as 'rock of the family' Davich: Valpo boy pinned under truck to be released from hospital: 'It's a miracle' NWI Business Ins and Outs: Coppolillo's Italian Steakhouse, Veleros Mexican Restaurant, New Age Baking Company, Chick-fil-A, Protein Bar & Kitchen, Chipotle, Chippopotamus and Play It Again Sports opening Pierogi Fest to return for 30th year, feature Blues Brothers impersonators, bluegrass-playing friars and a new 'Who is Smarter than a University of Chicago Physician' game show Coroner identifies deceased in Schererville crash Ex-Crown Point real estate agents indicted on charges of $5 million in COVID relief fraud after allegedly spending money on Porsche and country club Portage mom charged with leaving 4 young children 'to fend for themselves,' cops say Mother charged with neglect after 18-month-old overdoses National Weather Service issues tornado, severe thunderstorm warnings for Northwest Indiana 3 injured by runaway draft horse at LaPorte County Fair Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Milwaukee Brewers draft Lake Central pitcher Griffin Tobias Davich: Parishioners leave churches to follow Jesus' lead: 'A great moment for our churches' Porter County woman wanted over foster son's death arrested in Michigan Man molested girls, saying he wanted marriage, baby, Portage police say\n\nAt precisely 1 p.m. Monday, the \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" account posted one more word.\n\nThe wait was over.\n\n\"Yes.\"\n\n\"For a lot of people, this is a holiday,\" Ryan S. Clark, a devotee of the series and NHL writer for ESPN.com, told The Seattle Times on Monday.\n\nIt's a holiday steeped in nostalgia -- in midsummer marathons on prehistoric PlayStations, in triple-option offenses and players lost to time, in critical recruiting battles for fictional five-star safeties, in regional conferences (remember them?) and in-state rivalries.\n\n\"NCAA Football 14\" had 20 predecessors, dating to \"Bill Walsh College Football\" in 1993. It also had a frenzied following, a generation of football fans who developed dynasties -- chiseling national champions out of small-school Cinderellas.\n\n\"For me it was really cool, because I got to see really good teams and players that in 1998, in Minneapolis, I wasn't ever going to see play until the bowl game,\" said Dave Southorn, 42, who later covered Boise State football for The Idaho Statesman and The Athletic. \"You got this really good view of the college football landscape through that game.\n\n\"That really helped me, to be frank, as I was figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. I was like, 'Oh, this is cool.' I knew things that others didn't. Everyone was talking about Michigan or whoever. I was like, 'Have you heard of Tulane?' \"\n\nClark, likewise, celebrated the annual summer release with a weeklong marathon, as he and a friend staged a sport-wide tournament (modeled after the UEFA Champions League in European soccer) to establish supremacy.\n\n\"We did our own statistical tracking [of games],\" said Clark, 39, who traces the tournament to his high-school years in Florida from 1998 to 2002. \"We were absolute nerds about it, and we totally own it. We absolutely own it.\"\n\nConcluded Clark, who lives in Seattle: \"This is what we would do from 4 o'clock in the afternoon to 2 o'clock in the morning every day for a week.\"\n\nDecades later, the arrival of \"EA Sports College Football 25\" has attracted a similar response, flooding social-media feeds with flea flickers and stadium shots and shaking student sections. As 247Sports college football reporter and podcaster Bud Elliott posted Tuesday on X: \"The EA Sports College Football release has completely upstaged media days buzz. Search trends [online] are wild. To the point where talking college football on a college football show instead of talking about the video game is legit bad business.\"\n\nThe business of college football is also reflected in the game, as players must maneuver NIL deals and the transfer portal to retain top talent. An athlete's academics, leadership skills, health, training and brand all must be monitored.\n\nIndeed, a whole lot happened in the 4,025 days between the releases of \"NCAA Football 14\" and \"EA Sports College Football 25.\"\n\nFor the sport, the franchise ... and its fans.\n\n\"The last time this game came out, I wasn't yet engaged,\" Southorn said. \"I've been married for nine years now. That's how long it's been for me.\"\n\nJoked Clark on Monday morning, in a similar situation: \"When 1 o'clock rolls around, my wife understands that it was a great run for our marriage. We had a lot of great years. We put championships in the rafters. But I'm a ghost to her now, and she knows that, God bless her.\"\n\nSouthorn may soon count among the game-playing ghosts. The University of Colorado alum, who now handles content and communications for a hospital system in Idaho, requested off work Friday to reignite a former flame.\n\n\"Daycare is going to come in clutch,\" said the 42-year-old father and Carnation native. \"I'll get up, take [daughter Kennedy] to day care in the morning. Maybe I'll swing by the doughnut shop and grab something, and then just settle in. I'll probably order a pizza or something at lunch, because I don't want to move.\n\n\"I know I'm in a boat with a whole lot of people. When you get to 40ish and you've got kids, you don't have as much time. But I know I'm literally going to find ways to make time. Because we all need something.\"\n\nThis game, for some, is more than a silly aside -- or a time machine to a tournament lasting until 2 a.m. It's not just nostalgia wrapped in new graphics and updated uniforms.\n\nIt's also a referendum on college football's deepening divide, on the parity diluted by super conferences and media-rights money. It's an individual objection -- a place where Army and Akron and Appalachian State can overwhelm Alabama, where Washington State can pummel its former Pac-12 partners into apologetic pieces.\n\nIt's a place where former Notre Dame and Wake Forest quarterback Sam Hartman -- whose Demon Deacons never defeated Clemson in his five seasons as the starter -- can topple the Tigers, 105-34, as they did Tuesday.\n\n\"Just blowing off some steam...\" Hartman posted, along with a screen shot, on social media.\n\nIt's a place where anything is still possible, provided you can play.\n\n\"I think maybe in the back of our lizard brains, you have some control over it now. You can make the Cinderella story happen,\" Southorn said. \"You can build someone up, where realistically it probably wouldn't happen [in the current era of college football] because of NIL and conference affiliation. You can return it to the way it used to be and feel like college football is a little more even or fair. I think that's a big part of it.\"\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and {"uri": "8230931574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "02:25:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T02:25:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T02:24:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/sports/college/mike-vorel-why-return-of-college-football-25-is-a-holiday-for-beloved-video-games/article_4716a580-7f53-57f1-827d-775f7ae1eacd.html", "title": "Mike Vorel: Why return of 'College Football 25' is a holiday for beloved video game's fans", "body": "Mike Vorel, The Seattle Times\n\nSEATTLE -- In September, a social-media account called \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" began periodically posting one word:\n\n\"No.\"\n\nDays passed, and the \"Nos\" piled up. No. No. No. No. No. But for dedicated college football fans, the wait was even longer.\n\nBefore this week, Electronic Arts' most recent college football video game -- \"NCAA Football 14\" -- had been released on July 9, 2013. The series was then waylaid by legal disputes surrounding player likenesses, pitched into an 11-year purgatory while the sport painstakingly evolved.\n\nOf course, college athletes were finally permitted to be paid for utilizing their name, image and likeness (NIL) in 2021, which allowed EA to compensate the players it profits from. (Players who opted in received $600 ... and, of course, a copy of the game.)\n\nAt precisely 1 p.m. Monday, the \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" account posted one more word.\n\nThe wait was over.\n\n\"Yes.\"\n\n\"For a lot of people, this is a holiday,\" Ryan S. Clark, a devotee of the series and NHL writer for ESPN.com, told The Seattle Times on Monday.\n\nIt's a holiday steeped in nostalgia -- in midsummer marathons on prehistoric PlayStations, in triple-option offenses and players lost to time, in critical recruiting battles for fictional five-star safeties, in regional conferences (remember them?) and in-state rivalries.\n\n\"NCAA Football 14\" had 20 predecessors, dating to \"Bill Walsh College Football\" in 1993. It also had a frenzied following, a generation of football fans who developed dynasties -- chiseling national champions out of small-school Cinderellas.\n\n\"For me it was really cool, because I got to see really good teams and players that in 1998, in Minneapolis, I wasn't ever going to see play until the bowl game,\" said Dave Southorn, 42, who later covered Boise State football for The Idaho Statesman and The Athletic. \"You got this really good view of the college football landscape through that game.\n\n\"That really helped me, to be frank, as I was figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. I was like, 'Oh, this is cool.' I knew things that others didn't. Everyone was talking about Michigan or whoever. I was like, 'Have you heard of Tulane?' \"\n\nClark, likewise, celebrated the annual summer release with a weeklong marathon, as he and a friend staged a sport-wide tournament (modeled after the UEFA Champions League in European soccer) to establish supremacy.\n\n\"We did our own statistical tracking [of games],\" said Clark, 39, who traces the tournament to his high-school years in Florida from 1998 to 2002. \"We were absolute nerds about it, and we totally own it. We absolutely own it.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nConcluded Clark, who lives in Seattle: \"This is what we would do from 4 o'clock in the afternoon to 2 o'clock in the morning every day for a week.\"\n\nDecades later, the arrival of \"EA Sports College Football 25\" has attracted a similar response, flooding social-media feeds with flea flickers and stadium shots and shaking student sections. As 247Sports college football reporter and podcaster Bud Elliott posted Tuesday on X: \"The EA Sports College Football release has completely upstaged media days buzz. Search trends [online] are wild. To the point where talking college football on a college football show instead of talking about the video game is legit bad business.\"\n\nThe business of college football is also reflected in the game, as players must maneuver NIL deals and the transfer portal to retain top talent. An athlete's academics, leadership skills, health, training and brand all must be monitored.\n\nIndeed, a whole lot happened in the 4,025 days between the releases of \"NCAA Football 14\" and \"EA Sports College Football 25.\"\n\nFor the sport, the franchise ... and its fans.\n\n\"The last time this game came out, I wasn't yet engaged,\" Southorn said. \"I've been married for nine years now. That's how long it's been for me.\"\n\nJoked Clark on Monday morning, in a similar situation: \"When 1 o'clock rolls around, my wife understands that it was a great run for our marriage. We had a lot of great years. We put championships in the rafters. But I'm a ghost to her now, and she knows that, God bless her.\"\n\nSouthorn may soon count among the game-playing ghosts. The University of Colorado alum, who now handles content and communications for a hospital system in Idaho, requested off work Friday to reignite a former flame.\n\n\"Daycare is going to come in clutch,\" said the 42-year-old father and Carnation native. \"I'll get up, take [daughter Kennedy] to day care in the morning. Maybe I'll swing by the doughnut shop and grab something, and then just settle in. I'll probably order a pizza or something at lunch, because I don't want to move.\n\n\"I know I'm in a boat with a whole lot of people. When you get to 40ish and you've got kids, you don't have as much time. But I know I'm literally going to find ways to make time. Because we all need something.\"\n\nThis game, for some, is more than a silly aside -- or a time machine to a tournament lasting until 2 a.m. It's not just nostalgia wrapped in new graphics and updated uniforms.\n\nIt's also a referendum on college football's deepening divide, on the parity diluted by super conferences and media-rights money. It's an individual objection -- a place where Army and Akron and Appalachian State can overwhelm Alabama, where Washington State can pummel its former Pac-12 partners into apologetic pieces.\n\nIt's a place where former Notre Dame and Wake Forest quarterback Sam Hartman -- whose Demon Deacons never defeated Clemson in his five seasons as the starter -- can topple the Tigers, 105-34, as they did Tuesday.\n\n\"Just blowing off some steam...\" Hartman posted, along with a screen shot, on social media.\n\nIt's a place where anything is still possible, provided you can play.\n\n\"I think maybe in the back of our lizard brains, you have some control over it now. You can make the Cinderella story happen,\" Southorn said. \"You can build someone up, where realistically it probably wouldn't happen [in the current era of college football] because of NIL and conference affiliation. You can return it to the way it used to be and feel like college football is a little more even or fair. I think that's a big part of it.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes {"uri": "2024-07-426662766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "04:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T04:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T00:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2024-07-19/ea-sports-college-football-25-among-most-anticipated-sports-video-games-in-history-hits-the-market", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25, Among Most Anticipated Sports Video Games in History, Hits the Market", "body": "FILE - This combo of images provided by EA Sports, shows the video game covers for the new standard edition College Football 25, left, and Deluxe Edition College Football 25, featuring Texas' Quinn Ewers, Colorado's Travis Hunter, and Michigan's Donovan Edwards. EA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play it. (EA Sports via AP, File)\n\nEA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play.\n\nThe game officially launched Friday, with EA Sports increasing its server capacity during early access to handle the crush.\n\n\"To say we've been blown away by the excitement, energy and anticipation around College Football 25 over the past few months would be an understatement,\" EA Sports said in a blog post this week. \"Just like you, our team has had July 19 circled for months as the culmination of so much work and dedication to build this game, and the chance to see it in players' hands for the first time.\"\n\nEA Sports' college football games used to be released annually, a cultural icon in American sports for much of the franchise's existence. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. The video-game developer offered Bowl Subdivision players a minimum of $600 and a copy of the game to have their likeness included in it. More than 11,000 players accepted offers.\n\nEA Sports has said its goal for the game was \"to feel like a love letter to college football and its fans.\"\n\nSan Diego State and Colorado were among the schools hosting College Football 25 events this week. Across social platforms, athletes such as LeBron James, Tim Tebow and Michael Vick -- even comedians Shane Gillis and Dan Soder -- were live-streaming head-to-head matches in the game.\n\nMichigan running back Donovan Edwards, one of the cover athletes, said in May some of the best moments of his childhood involved playing EA Sports college football with his best friend.\n\n\"Just for it to be back, as well as to be on the cover of it, it's an awesome feeling,\" he said.\n\nThe game's other standard-edition cover athletes are Texas quarterback Quinn Ewers and Colorado two-way player Travis Hunter. The deluxe edition features the backs of numerous players in a stadium tunnel, including Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe, Georgia quarterback Carson Beck and Ohio State running back Quinshon Judkins.\n\nEA Sports' college football franchise dates to the 1990s. It grew in popularity in the early 2000s as gaming systems became more advanced, allowing for revolutionary game modes such as the popular Race for the Heisman create-a-player that was introduced in NCAA Football 06.\n\nThat edition also featured historic teams, including the 1992 Alabama squad that Clemson coach Dabo Swinney played on.\n\n\"Sleeping on me a little bit,\" Swinney joked about the 70 overall rating for his player, \"WR No. 88,\" which did, however, have a 91 speed rating. \"They must have my going down the Hill speed. I appreciate the love they gave me on that.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Pete Iacobelli contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAP college football: https://apnews.com/hub/ap-top-25-college-football-poll and https://apnews.com/hub/college-football. {"uri": "8233928613", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:33:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:33:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:33:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.wccbcharlotte.com/2024/07/19/ea-sports-college-football-25-among-most-anticipated-sports-video-games-in-history-hits-the-market/", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25, Among Most Anticipated Sports Video Games In History, Hits The Market - WCCB Charlotte's CW", "body": "EA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play.\n\nThe game officially launched Friday, with EA Sports increasing its server capacity ahead of time to handle the crush. More than 2.2 million people had already played the game during an early-access period before launch.\n\n\"To say we've been blown away by the excitement, energy and anticipation around College Football 25 over the past few months would be an understatement,\" EA Sports said in a blog post this week. \"Just like you, our team has had July 19 circled for months as the culmination of so much work and dedication to build this game, and the chance to see it in players' hands for the first time.\"\n\nEA Sports' college football games used to be released annually, a cultural icon in American sports for much of the franchise's existence. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. The video-game developer offered Bowl Subdivision players a minimum of $600 and a copy of the game to have their likeness included in it. More than 11,000 players accepted offers.\n\nThe National College Players Association, a group that has long advocated for college players to be paid, celebrated the game as a milestone for its mission.\n\n\"It's exciting for me, my teammates, and my friends from other schools to be in the game and get paid,\" Washington defensive back and NCPA leader Dyson McCutcheon said in a press release. \"I've been playing this game all week. I know lot of people before me fought for this and I'm grateful.\"\n\nEA Sports has said its goal for the game was \"to feel like a love letter to college football and its fans.\"\n\nUCLA, Mississippi State, San Diego State and Colorado were among the schools hosting College Football 25 events this week. Across social platforms, athletes such as LeBron James, Tim Tebow and Michael Vick -- even comedians Shane Gillis and Dan Soder -- were live-streaming head-to-head matches in the game.\n\nMichigan running back Donovan Edwards, one of the cover athletes, said in May some of the best moments of his childhood involved playing EA Sports college football with his best friend.\n\n\"Just for it to be back, as well as to be on the cover of it, it's an awesome feeling,\" he said.\n\nThe game's other standard-edition cover athletes are Texas quarterback Quinn Ewers and Colorado two-way player Travis Hunter. The deluxe edition features the backs of numerous players in a stadium tunnel, including Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe, Georgia quarterback Carson Beck and Ohio State running back Quinshon Judkins.\n\nEA Sports' college football franchise dates to the 1990s. It grew in popularity in the early 2000s as gaming systems became more advanced, allowing for revolutionary game modes such as the popular Race for the Heisman create-a-player that was introduced in NCAA Football 06.\n\nThat edition also featured historic teams, including the 1992 Alabama squad that Clemson coach Dabo Swinney played on.\n\n\"Sleeping on me a little bit,\" Swinney joked about the 70 overall rating for his player, \"WR No. 88,\" which did, however, have a 91 speed rating. \"They must have my going down the Hill speed. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. {"uri": "8233997816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:35:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:35:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:35:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.gamespot.com/articles/college-football-25-review-roundup/1100-6525155/", "title": "College Football 25 Review Roundup", "body": "Here's what the critics are saying about EA's first new college football game in 10 years.\n\nAfter more than a decade away, EA's college football series returns with EA Sports College Football 25. The game was initially released on July 15 in early access but is out now for everyone.\n\nAfter so many years away, many might be wondering if the wait has indeed been worth it. In this post, we're rounding up review scores and excerpts to help you decide if the game may be worth your time and money.\n\nIf you're curious but don't necessarily want to buy the game right away, EA Play subscribers have access to a 10-hour trial right now; Game Pass Ultimate members have this benefit as well since the membership includes EA Play.\n\nCollege Football 25 is already doing well, as the game reached 2.2 million unique players during the early-access window, while another 600,000 people have tried the EA Play trial.\n\nEA's last college football game before this was 2013's NCAA Football 14. EA and the NCAA broke off their partnership due to a variety of reasons, including legal problems and lawsuits. Instead, EA brokered separate licensing deals to feature all 134 FBS schools in College Football 25. And in a major change, EA is paying athletes to be in the game as part of Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) deals.\n\nCollege Football 25 is available on console for PS5 and Xbox Series X|S, but not last-gen consoles, PC, or Nintendo Switch.\n\nIf you're just getting started with College Football 25, you may want to check out GameSpot's College Football 25 launch guide.\n\nYou can see a sampling of review scores for College Football 25 below. For more on the critical reaction, be sure to visit GameSpot sister site Metacritic.\n\n\"College Football 25's presentation is light-years beyond what developer EA Orlando has been doing with Madden. You can see sweat on individual players, the lighting is exceptional, and everything pops visually in a way that Madden just doesn't. There's also just a lot more stuff to enjoy, from the unique intros for each team as they take the field to mascots dancing around when their school pulls off a big play.\" -- Will Borger [Full review]\n\n\"When I heard EA was bringing college football back, I was fully prepared to play a game of Madden with college uniforms. In all honesty, I would have played it and been mildly satisfied. EA delivered a much deeper experience that easily carves its own identity in every way possible. Once EA learns its way around the restrictions of the NIL situation, the series will go to an even higher level.\" -- Brian Mazique [Full review]\n\nIt's a testament to what is possible with sports games when teams have longer than a few months to crank out AAA titles. And if this is the foundation for future college football games, then the series is in a very, very good place.\" -- Matt Brown [Full review]\n\n\"From nowhere, it's suddenly the sports game that all others have to beat.\" -- Ben Wilson [Full review]\n\n\"EA put all of its chips into College Football 25, and it truly paid off. People are buying consoles just to play this game. It's a cultural phenomenon and the experience that's provided isn't replicated anywhere else. All the new additions to help make the game stand out including Wear and Tear, Turbo Mode, different coverage shells and added hot routes for pre-play, and basically everything added isn't just a gimmick, it's a substantial change. While some bugs and logic need to be addressed, College Football 25 is undoubtedly the most fun football game to come out in years. Everything College Football is here.\" -- Cory Wells [Full review]", "source": {"uri": "gamespot.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GameSpot"}, "authors": [{"uri": "eddie_makuch@gamespot.com", {"uri": "2024-07-425384132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "01:18:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T01:18:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T01:16:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/sports/article290182004.html", "title": "Mike Vorel: Why return of 'College Football 25' is a holiday for beloved video game's fans", "body": "SEATTLE - In September, a social-media account called \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" began periodically posting one word:\n\n\"No.\"\n\nDays passed, and the \"Nos\" piled up. No. No. No. No. No. But for dedicated college football fans, the wait was even longer.\n\nBefore this week, Electronic Arts' most recent college football video game - \"NCAA Football 14\" - had been released on July 9, 2013. The series was then waylaid by legal disputes surrounding player likenesses, pitched into an 11-year purgatory while the sport painstakingly evolved.\n\nOf course, college athletes were finally permitted to be paid for utilizing their name, image and likeness (NIL) in 2021, which allowed EA to compensate the players it profits from. (Players who opted in received $600 ... and, of course, a copy of the game.)\n\nAt precisely 1 p.m. Monday, the \"Is EA Sports College Football Out\" account posted one more word.\n\n\"For a lot of people, this is a holiday,\" Ryan S. Clark, a devotee of the series and NHL writer for ESPN.com, told The Seattle Times on Monday.\n\nIt's a holiday steeped in nostalgia - in midsummer marathons on prehistoric PlayStations, in triple-option offenses and players lost to time, in critical recruiting battles for fictional five-star safeties, in regional conferences (remember them?) and in-state rivalries.\n\n\"NCAA Football 14\" had 20 predecessors, dating to \"Bill Walsh College Football\" in 1993. It also had a frenzied following, a generation of football fans who developed dynasties - chiseling national champions out of small-school Cinderellas.\n\n\"For me it was really cool, because I got to see really good teams and players that in 1998, in Minneapolis, I wasn't ever going to see play until the bowl game,\" said Dave Southorn, 42, who later covered Boise State football for The Idaho Statesman and The Athletic. \"You got this really good view of the college football landscape through that game.\n\n\"That really helped me, to be frank, as I was figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. I was like, 'Oh, this is cool.' I knew things that others didn't. Everyone was talking about Michigan or whoever. I was like, 'Have you heard of Tulane?' \"\n\nClark, likewise, celebrated the annual summer release with a weeklong marathon, as he and a friend staged a sport-wide tournament (modeled after the UEFA Champions League in European soccer) to establish supremacy.\n\n\"We did our own statistical tracking [of games],\" said Clark, 39, who traces the tournament to his high-school years in Florida from 1998 to 2002. \"We were absolute nerds about it, and we totally own it. We absolutely own it.\"\n\nConcluded Clark, who lives in Seattle: \"This is what we would do from 4 o'clock in the afternoon to 2 o'clock in the morning every day for a week.\"\n\nDecades later, the arrival of \"EA Sports College Football 25\" has attracted a similar response, flooding social-media feeds with flea flickers and stadium shots and shaking student sections. As 247Sports college football reporter and podcaster Bud Elliott posted Tuesday on X: \"The EA Sports College Football release has completely upstaged media days buzz. Search trends [online] are wild. To the point where talking college football on a college football show instead of talking about the video game is legit bad business.\"\n\nThe business of college football is also reflected in the game, as players must maneuver NIL deals and the transfer portal to retain top talent. An athlete's academics, leadership skills, health, training and brand all must be monitored.\n\nIndeed, a whole lot happened in the 4,025 days between the releases of \"NCAA Football 14\" and \"EA Sports College Football 25.\"\n\nFor the sport, the franchise ... and its fans.\n\n\"The last time this game came out, I wasn't yet engaged,\" Southorn said. \"I've been married for nine years now. That's how long it's been for me.\"\n\nJoked Clark on Monday morning, in a similar situation: \"When 1 o'clock rolls around, my wife understands that it was a great run for our marriage. We had a lot of great years. We put championships in the rafters. But I'm a ghost to her now, and she knows that, God bless her.\"\n\nSouthorn may soon count among the game-playing ghosts. The University of Colorado alum, who now handles content and communications for a hospital system in Idaho, requested off work Friday to reignite a former flame.\n\n\"Daycare is going to come in clutch,\" said the 42-year-old father and Carnation native. \"I'll get up, take [daughter Kennedy] to day care in the morning. Maybe I'll swing by the doughnut shop and grab something, and then just settle in. I'll probably order a pizza or something at lunch, because I don't want to move.\n\n\"I know I'm in a boat with a whole lot of people. When you get to 40ish and you've got kids, you don't have as much time. But I know I'm literally going to find ways to make time. Because we all need something.\"\n\nThis game, for some, is more than a silly aside - or a time machine to a tournament lasting until 2 a.m. It's not just nostalgia wrapped in new graphics and updated uniforms.\n\nIt's also a referendum on college football's deepening divide, on the parity diluted by super conferences and media-rights money. It's an individual objection - a place where Army and Akron and Appalachian State can overwhelm Alabama, where Washington State can pummel its former Pac-12 partners into apologetic pieces.\n\nIt's a place where former Notre Dame and Wake Forest quarterback Sam Hartman - whose Demon Deacons never defeated Clemson in his five seasons as the starter - can topple the Tigers, 105-34, as they did Tuesday.\n\n\"Just blowing off some steam...\" Hartman posted, along with a screen shot, on social media.\n\nIt's a place where anything is still possible, provided you can play.\n\n\"I think maybe in the back of our lizard brains, you have some control over it now. You can make the Cinderella story happen,\" Southorn said. \"You can build someone up, where realistically it probably wouldn't happen [in the current era of college football] because of NIL and conference affiliation. You can return it to the way it used to be and feel like college football is a little more even or fair. I think that's a big part of it.\"", "source": {"uri": "bradenton.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bradenton Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mike_vorel@bradenton.com", "name": "Mike Vorel", "type": {"uri": "8233019963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "07:19:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T07:19:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T07:17:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13650515/EA-Sports-College-Football-25-anticipated-sports-video-games-history-hits-market.html", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25, among most anticipated sports video...", "body": "EA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play.\n\nThe game officially launched Friday, with EA Sports increasing its server capacity during early access to handle the crush.\n\n\"To say we\u00b4ve been blown away by the excitement, energy and anticipation around College Football 25 over the past few months would be an understatement,\" EA Sports said in a blog post this week. \"Just like you, our team has had July 19 circled for months as the culmination of so much work and dedication to build this game, and the chance to see it in players\u00b4 hands for the first time.\"\n\nEA Sports' college football games used to be released annually, a cultural icon in American sports for much of the franchise's existence. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. The video-game developer offered Bowl Subdivision players a minimum of $600 and a copy of the game to have their likeness included in it. More than 11,000 players accepted offers.\n\nEA Sports has said its goal for the game was \"to feel like a love letter to college football and its fans.\"\n\nSan Diego State and Colorado were among the schools hosting College Football 25 events this week. Across social platforms, athletes such as LeBron James, Tim Tebow and Michael Vick - even comedians Shane Gillis and Dan Soder - were live-streaming head-to-head matches in the game.\n\nMichigan running back Donovan Edwards, one of the cover athletes, said in May some of the best moments of his childhood involved playing EA Sports college football with his best friend.\n\n\"Just for it to be back, as well as to be on the cover of it, it\u00b4s an awesome feeling,\" he said.\n\nThe game's other standard-edition cover athletes are Texas quarterback Quinn Ewers and Colorado two-way player Travis Hunter. The deluxe edition features the backs of numerous players in a stadium tunnel, including Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe, Georgia quarterback Carson Beck and Ohio State running back Quinshon Judkins.\n\nEA Sports' college football franchise dates to the 1990s. It grew in popularity in the early 2000s as gaming systems became more advanced, allowing for revolutionary game modes such as the popular Race for the Heisman create-a-player that was introduced in NCAA Football 06.\n\nThat edition also featured historic teams, including the 1992 Alabama squad that Clemson coach Dabo Swinney played on.\n\n\"Sleeping on me a little bit,\" Swinney joked about the 70 overall rating for his player, \"WR No. 88,\" which did, however, have a 91 speed rating. \"They must have my going down the Hill speed. I appreciate the love they gave me on that.\"\n\nAP Sports Writer Pete Iacobelli contributed to this report.\n\nAP college football: https://apnews.com/hub/ap-top-25-college-football-poll and https://apnews.com/hub/college-football. {"uri": "8234098549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:14:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:14:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:14:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.windowscentral.com/gaming/ea-sports-college-football-25-soars-to-3-on-xbox-us-daily-active-users-4-on-ps5-as-the-game-fans-waited-11-years-for-launches-worldwide", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25 soars to #3 on Xbox US daily active users, #4 on PS5, as the game fans waited 11 years for launches worldwide", "body": "Michigan Wolverines running back Donovan Edwards in EA Sports College Football 25. (Image credit: Electronic Arts)\n\nOne of the most highly anticipated sports games in history, EA Sports College Football 25, is finally here -- and it's already become a top seller on Xbox Series X|S and PlayStation 5.\n\nThat news comes from Mat Piscatella, executive director and video game industry advisor at the market research firm Circana. According to a recent post from Piscatella, data from Circana's Player Engagement Tracker indicates that on July 17, the game ranked #3 in US daily active users on Xbox and #4 on PS5, with the megahit only falling short of titles like Call of Duty, Fortnite, and Grand Theft Auto V.\n\nNotably, this data was drawn before the game even left early access and launched for everyone who purchased the game on Friday. That means the players who helped EA Sports College Football 25 hit this milestone were all folks who spent $100 to preorder the Deluxe Edition of the game -- and also that its daily active users count will likely skyrocket even higher now that buyers of the standard $69.99 edition can jump in.\n\nHistorically, sports games have always been popular, but even with that in mind, the explosive success of EA Sports College Football 25 stands out. There's a good reason for it, though: there hasn't been a college football video game in over 11 years, with the last before this one being 2013's NCAA Football 14 on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3. That makes publisher Electronic Arts' (EA) new game a uniquely special release, and one that fans have waited more than a decade for.\n\nThe reason behind the hiatus is a legal one; after NCAA Football 14's release, EA and its licensing partner, the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), faced a lawsuit from college football players who argued their likeness was used in the game without compensation. As part of its settlement, EA said it wouldn't make new college football games, but after the US Supreme Court ruled the NCAA's tendency to avoid fiscal compensation was a breach of antitrust law in the 2021 NCAA v. Alston case, the NCAA created new rules for likeness compensation. In 2023, EA then spoke with ESPN, announcing that players would have the option to opt into appearing in a new 2024 college football game and that they would be compensated for doing so.\n\nWith both this context and the extreme popularity of college football in the US in mind, it's easy to see why EA Sports College Football 25 is blowing up. Note that while there aren't publicly available player counts at the time of writing, Piscatella posted a humorous GIF on Friday that makes it clear the game is performing very, very well.\n\nI don't enjoy sports games myself, but even so, it's awesome to see those who do finally get a new college football entry after 11 years. Since 2013, fans have had to rely on community-made NCAA Football 14 mods to enjoy a somewhat modern college football gaming experience. Not anymore.\n\nOne disappointing thing about the new game is that it's not available on Windows PC through any platform or service, which I'd guess is due to concerns about mods and licensing (perhaps the game will come to PC eventually; after all, Madden is on it). Its exclusivity to Xbox Series X|S and PS5 does make it something of a system seller for those consoles, though, as unlike most new EA Sports games, it's not playable on the last-gen Xbox One or PS4.\n\nEA Sports College Football 25 is also not available on Xbox Game Pass, which is Microsoft's buffet-style subscription service that gives members access to hundreds of games for a monthly fee. It is, however, discounted by $7 for EA Play members, which you get with Xbox Game Pass Ultimate for no additional cost (in time, it may also become fully playable through EA Play). Sony's PlayStation Plus does not include EA Play in any tier, so if you have Game Pass Ultimate already, Xbox is the best place to play.", "source": {"uri": "windowscentral.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-426667123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "04:23:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T04:23:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T04:04:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/ea-sports-college-football-25-among-most-anticipated-sports-video-games-in-history-hits-the/article_8b370fc7-fd85-51a8-9565-6c6d358e4c7b.html", "title": "EA Sports College Football 25, among most anticipated sports video games in history, hits the market", "body": "FILE - Texas quarterback Arch Manning (16) warms up before an NCAA college football game against Rice in Austin, Texas, Saturday, Sept. 2, 2023. Manning announced Tuesday, July 9, 2024, his likeness will be used in EA Sports College Football 25 following reports he had declined the game developer's offer to be featured in it.\n\nEA Sports College Football 25, among the most highly anticipated sports video games of all time, has flooded the market as gamers who waited more than a decade for the franchise's next installment rush to play.\n\nThe game officially launched Friday, with EA Sports increasing its server capacity during early access to handle the crush.\n\n\"To say we've been blown away by the excitement, energy and anticipation around College Football 25 over the past few months would be an understatement,\" EA Sports said in a blog post this week. \"Just like you, our team has had July 19 circled for months as the culmination of so much work and dedication to build this game, and the chance to see it in players' hands for the first time.\"\n\nEA Sports' college football games used to be released annually, a cultural icon in American sports for much of the franchise's existence. The company froze future editions in 2013 when athletes began questioning why they weren't getting paid to be featured in the games.\n\nWith athlete compensation rights sorted out in court and now allowed by the NCAA, EA Sports announced in 2021 it would be reviving the franchise. The video-game developer offered Bowl Subdivision players a minimum of $600 and a copy of the game to have their likeness included in it. More than 11,000 players accepted offers.\n\nEA Sports has said its goal for the game was \"to feel like a love letter to college football and its fans.\"\n\nSan Diego State and Colorado were among the schools hosting College Football 25 events this week. Across social platforms, athletes such as LeBron James, Tim Tebow and Michael Vick -- even comedians Shane Gillis and Dan Soder -- were live-streaming head-to-head matches in the game.\n\nMichigan running back Donovan Edwards, one of the cover athletes, said in May some of the best moments of his childhood involved playing EA Sports college football with his best friend.\n\n\"Just for it to be back, as well as to be on the cover of it, it's an awesome feeling,\" he said.\n\nThe game's other standard-edition cover athletes are Texas quarterback Quinn Ewers and Colorado two-way player Travis Hunter. The deluxe edition features the backs of numerous players in a stadium tunnel, including Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe, Georgia quarterback Carson Beck and Ohio State running back Quinshon Judkins.\n\nEA Sports' college football franchise dates to the 1990s. It grew in popularity in the early 2000s as gaming systems became more advanced, allowing for revolutionary game modes such as the popular Race for the Heisman create-a-player that was introduced in NCAA Football 06.\n\nThat edition also featured historic teams, including the 1992 Alabama squad that Clemson coach Dabo Swinney played on.\n\n\"Sleeping on me a little bit,\" Swinney joked about the 70 overall rating for his player, \"WR No. 88,\" which did, however, have a 91 speed rating. \"They must have my going down the Hill speed. I appreciate the love they gave me on that.\"\n\nAP Sports Writer Pete Iacobelli contributed to this report.\n\nAP college football: https://apnews.com/hub/ap-top-25-college-football-poll and https://apnews.com/hub/college-football. EA Sports revealed that around 2.2 million people played the game during its three-day early access period.\n\nThe only want to get into early access was to preorder the deluxe edition, which cost $100. So this announcement implies that millions of people paid at least an extra $30 to get an extra 72 hours of playtime before anybody else on Xbox Series X/S and PlayStation 5. In addition, more than 600,000 players got in via an EA Play trial. It's unclear if the 2.2 million number refers to both deluxe edition owners and EA Play subscribers, however.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\n'This game is for the fans, and the response we've seen from across the collegiate landscape, athletes, creators, celebrities, and the core community has been nothing short of spectacular,\" Daryl Holt, senior vice president of EA Sports, said in the press release.\n\nThis is a momentous release for EA Sports. It's the first time EA has released a college football video game since NCAA Football 14 in 2013. At the time, the NCAA didn't allow college athletes to get paid for their likenesses, so EA used fake names. This caused some friction between the two entities, so the contract wasn't renewed. EA Sports announced it was getting back into college football in 2021. This time around, EA was able to use real athletes because the NCAA changed its position on paying its players.\n\nCollege Football 25, by many accounts, is also an excellent sports game. Digital Trends' Tomas Franzese called it \"the best EA Sports game that I've played in years\" thanks to new modes that allow for more customization and deeper gameplay. It also looks fantastic thanks to the Frostbite Engine.\n\nIn other College Football 25 news, according to multiple reports, the players were paid a minimum of $600 for their name, image, and likeness, referred to as NIL. They also got a free copy of the game. This includes every player who submitted, says the New York Times, while those who were featured more prominently in the game's marketing or were on the box cover were paid more. That amounts to around 14,000 players, although less than 100 will be featured.\n\n\"Ninety-plus percent of these athletes will never have [another] NIL opportunity ...
