{"uri": "8230750348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-17", "time": "22:39:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-17T22:39:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-17T22:39:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.ign.com/articles/college-football-25-review", "title": "College Football 25 Review in Progress - IGN", "body": "So far dynamic matches and stellar visuals can't help the feeling that this prospect was rushed to the field too soon.\n\nAbout a week before College Football 25's play-early-if-you-give-EA-more-money release, I found myself at a friend's wedding in Texas, overhearing someone with plans to buy a brand new console just to be able to get this game. I knew the long-awaited return of an NCAA video game was going to be popular, but I didn't realize it was going to be system-selling levels of enticing. I've thought about that guy a lot as I've played College Football 25 over the last week, and about how excited he was - I wonder if he's bought it yet, and if he's having a good time, because so far my own experience as a longtime Madden player has been... mixed. The on-field action and visuals are generally stellar, but the barebones modes, awful UI, lack of tutorials, and slew of other annoyances and poor design choices have made everything else about it a pretty joyless slog so far.\n\nLet's get the good stuff out of the way first: College Football 25's presentation is light-years beyond what developer EA Orlando has been doing with Madden. You can see sweat on individual players, the lighting is exceptional, and everything pops visually in a way that Madden just doesn't. There's also just a lot more stuff to enjoy, from the unique intros for each team as they take the field to mascots dancing around when their school pulls off a big play. There's even performances from cheerleaders, school-specific cheers, and live cuts to the crowd reacting to what's happening in real time. College Football 25 captures a lot of the pageantry and tradition that makes college football unique, and that makes it feel unique, too. I hope some of this added focus on presentation will make it over to Madden in the next few years.\n\nThe other major difference is that it just feels faster and a whole lot more fluid. Plays happen more quickly, there's less delay between them, and players feel like they're moving more nimbly, too. When real-life players make the transition from college to the NFL, you'll often hear them talk about having to adapt to the faster speed of the NFL game - here, though, it's the other way around, and it makes College Football 25 feel dynamic in a way that Madden doesn't.\n\nThere are also a lot of nice little touches throughout. I like how selecting your favorite team (which you do by choosing their helmet, not a name from a list) decorates the main menu with photos of their mascot, stadium, and other cool, team-specific things like ticket stubs, or how the loading screens and on-field play art looks like they've been drawn by hand. College Football 25 has personality. Oh, and unlike Madden 24, there's no menu lag. It's the little things.\n\nAs far as modes go, though, things are a little barebones. You've got your standard Play Now feature for jumping into a quick game; Road to the College Football playoffs, which is an online ranked mode where you'll pick a team and try to guide them to a National Championship; Road to Glory, which lets you create your own player and pilot them through their college career; Dynasty, where you'll helm one of College Football 25's 134 (!) teams as either a head coach or an offensive or defensive coordinator; Practice and Mini-Games modes; and finally, College Ultimate Team (CUT), the college version of Madden Ultimate Team, which is still a slot machine masquerading as a trading card game that will almost assuredly make EA hundreds of millions of dollars and eventually earn the ire of the player base as it gets more updates on a yearly basis than every other mode combined. Cynical? Maybe, but we've seen this movie before.\n\nEA's servers have been something of a mess since launch, so I haven't really gotten to play much Dynasty yet - whenever I try to make a Dynasty league, it always fails to download the latest rosters from EA's servers or sign my coach's contract) - but I have messed around with the other modes, and so far, I'm pretty whelmed. I've spent the most time in Road to Glory, so let's start there.\n\nDisappointingly, there are no high school games to play in Road to Glory as there were in NCAA Football 14. Instead, you spawn your player from the ether, choose a position (you can play as a QB, HB, WR, MLB, or CB), and determine whether you want to start as a 5-star, 4-star, 3-star, or 2-star recruit. The better you are as a prospect, the sooner you'll see the field, and the better you'll play when you do, but starting off as a less desirable recruit is more challenging, and ultimately, more rewarding if you manage to make it to a starting position. (After all, everyone loves an underdog story.) I started as a 5-star QB named Joe Throw who got picked up by 5-star Michigan because I already work hard enough at my day job, thank you very much, and it's been... not great.\n\nEach week, you'll allocate Rest Points to stats like Academics, Health, Training, Leadership, Brand, and so on. You only have so many, and sometimes you'll get a text from a sponsor offering you an endorsement deal or from your academic advisor offering some extra study time, which will take up a good chunk of your weekly allotment. Spending points the right way is important because you have to maintain a certain GPA and don't want to be so tired you open yourself up to injury. So far, however, it's pretty basic resource management and the lack of any cutscenes means you're mostly just navigating menus. Think of a somehow more barebones version of Madden's already barebones Superstar mode, and you're on the right track.\n\nWhat's really frustrating, though, is the on-field Road to Glory experience. As a quarterback, you're only given one play call option each down, and you''ll have to run that play unless you spend limited Play Change points to unlock two other choices. Earn more of your coach's trust by playing well and spend your Rest Points wisely throughout the week, and you'll get more plays to choose from. Makes sense, right? The issue is that even with maximum trust, you seemingly can't audible, so if the plays you are given look like a bad fit against what the defense is showing you, there's nothing you can do besides hot route your receivers on passing plays and hope it works out. On running plays? You're out of luck, Jack.\n\nAnd even if you spent the Play Change points, you're still limited in what you can call, and sometimes it barely makes a difference anyway. If you don't want a running play and spend a Play Change point, there's no guarantee you won't get two more running plays. Spending a point and getting what are essentially two more versions of the same play feels bad because you don't earn more points as a game goes on. I get that this restriction is meant to simulate building your coach's trust, and that's all well and good, but at least let me have one or two pre-approved audibles. Give me something. Don't get me wrong: Michigan is, as of now, undefeated; Joe Throw is almighty. But I'm not having that much fun winning.\n\nCollege Ultimate Team is... Ultimate Team. The Challenges you have to do to progress are boring, and it's designed to take annoyingly long so that even decent players start to think opening their wallets isn't a bad idea. College Football 25's real sin, however, is locking all of the tutorial content inside Ultimate Team. Madden's excellent Skills Trainer, which will walk you through everything from basic gameplay to identifying and beating certain defensive coverages? Not here. Instead, it's been replaced with Ultimate Team Challenges, and the change is as bad as it sounds. One early one put me inside the red zone and tasked me with throwing a lob pass. You know, the kind you throw on deep balls after your receiver beats their corner and is running free down the field. And because it's Ultimate Team and not the Skills Trainer, you have to choose the right play from your playbook, and make the pass in a single try. Otherwise, you're staring at the \"Challenge Failed\" message over and over and over again. Remember, this is meant to be a tutorial.\n\nIt's hard not to be deeply cynical about this design choice. Surely EA Orlando could have taken the Skills Trainer, which has existed in Madden for several years, and put another version of it into College Football 25. The only reason to do it this way is to encourage new players to go into CUT - of course, they'd have to realize that the tutorials are in CUT in the first place, which is something College Football 25 doesn't advertise at all. As someone who doesn't play Ultimate Team beyond the review period for obvious reasons, I just assumed that there were no tutorials at all and EA simply wanted college football-loving folk who don't regularly play Madden to suffer. In actuality, however, they want them to get hooked on CUT and spend lots and lots of money. I'm not sure which is worse.\n\nAnd then there are things that just don't make sense. Every CPU team I've played so far loves to run a no-huddle offense, but College Football 25 does not simulate the time between plays unless you turn on the accelerated clock option in the menus. Teams otherwise come to the line instantaneously, which, aside from being annoying and making everyone on your defense very tired very quickly, means games last far longer than they should. The mini-games, which are generally more fun and varied than Madden's (though some, like WR Battle, are one-to-one recreations), have a scoring system so strict they are impossible to get gold medals on unless you play perfectly. Bafflingly, there's also no option to restart a mini-game if you finish it and don't like your score, as there is in Madden, so I've found myself picking easy ones like Option Attack and just running them over and over again to spend as little time with them as possible. If you want to restart a mini-game to try and hit a higher score after you've completed it, you have to close and reopen the entire game.\n\nAnd while College Football 25's visuals are generally wonderful, the UI is, to put it kindly, atrocious. Madden has an automated hat count, which will show you how many defenders are lined up in both sides of the box on running plays and whether or not you have an advantage in blockers on either side. It's not there in College Football, so you'd better know how to do that yourself. (I hope you like playing the CUT tutorials!) The \"previous play\" arts showing you the last play the offense and defense ran are hidden unless you flick the right stick to bring up that menu, which isn't immediately obvious. It's hard to see how much stamina defensive linemen have because, unlike the bar used in Madden, stamina in College Football 25 is represented by small blue circles over their heads that are hard to see, especially if you're zoomed out. There are no on-screen notifications telling you what type of pass you just threw, whether you landed a hit stick, whether that pick you just got was perfectly timed, or anything else.\n\nGod help you if you'd like to actually see what abilities your players have mid-match because the icons were made for ants. And while play arts look great on the field, the ones in your playbook are a step down from what recent Maddens have offered. Oh, and then there's the genuinely embarrassing things, like certain schools having outdated logos - EA has publicly admitted to Stanford, Western Michigan, and Jacksonville State already - and certain player likenesses being inaccurate. I understand that College Football 25 is a massive undertaking, and EA hasn't made a game like this in a long time, but the whole thing feels rushed, incomplete, and in a lot of ways, not up to par with Madden, much less the other sports games that Madden already wasn't up to par with, which is basically all of them.\n\nI still find myself thinking a lot about that guy I overheard at my friend's wedding, a person who is buying a $500 console just to play this game. I wonder if he, as someone who doesn't play a lot of video games, is having fun - because despite the NCAA's wider appeal, so far it feels like anyone who doesn't already know how to play EA's football games is going to have a really bad time with College Football 25. Even as someone who plays way too much Madden, the stuff that's not here is both baffling and infuriating. It's barebones, sports poor UI design, has tutorials that range from \"bad\" to \"non-existent,\" and features a number of other frustrations that simply shouldn't be here. Oh, and I really don't appreciate seeing an Ultimate Team pop-up every time I exit every other game mode. I know it's there, EA. We all do. I just don't want to play it.\n\nMaybe Dynasty will change things once the servers get sorted out and I can finally play it. Maybe that's what makes everything click. I have a lot more to see and a lot more to play. The on-field game is fun! The presentation is excellent! But everything, and I do mean everything, surrounding those things makes me want to go lie down in a dark room for a few hours and think about the choices I've made to reach this moment. Maybe, by the time I have my final thoughts ready sometime next week, everything will click. But right now, EA College Football 25 feels like a college quarterback who left school for the NFL too soon, got drafted way higher than he should have because a team was desperate, started under intense scrutiny from a fanbase and an owner who are tired of losing all the time, and then flamed out of the league because he just wasn't ready for prime time. You always wonder what might have been with a player like that. Sometimes, it's better not to rush, and instead spend an extra year honing your skills. You'd think the publisher behind Madden, of all things, would understand that.", "source": {"uri": "ign.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "IGN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Complete guide to newly released NCAA video game", "body": "After a decade-long drought, NCAA video games are finally making a return. College Football 25 is one of the year's most anticipated releases, set to come out Friday, July 19.\n\nIf you're wondering why you've seen the latest NCAA football video game all over your timeline, it's because fans who pre-ordered the Deluxe Edition were given early access to the game Monday, July 15th.\n\nThose who patiently waited for the Standard Edition release will now also have access -- and they have their plans carved out for the entire weekend.\n\nWhat consoles is College Football 25 available on? The Sporting News has answers to all of your gaming compatibility questions below.\n\nMORE: EA Sports College Football 25 player rankings\n\nPC and current-gen console owners -- like Xbox One and PlayStation 4 -- are not going to be happy about this. College Football 25 is only available on the two next-gen consoles. That means users will have to upgrade their systems to either PlayStation 5 or Xbox Series X|S if they wish to play the new NCAA football video game.\n\nYou can find College Football 25's playable consoles below:\n\nCollege Football 25 has three different editions with varying prices. You can read more about what comes with each edition here and find the prices below.\n\nUnfortunately for current-gen gamers, College Football 25 is not backward compatible.\n\nThe game is only being released on next-gen consoles like PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S. {"uri": "8233767282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:30:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:30:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:29:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://sea.mashable.com/ea-college-football-25/33493/ea-sports-college-football-25-review-why-it-puts-madden-to-shame", "title": "'EA Sports College Football 25' review: Why it puts 'Madden' to shame", "body": "The sim engine is busted Flat commentary Frostbite engine-related bugs/glitches Lack of depth in marquee modes\n\nIt's cliche to say but college football is back. And it only feels trite to say, because at this point, despite all the hype, the memes, the teasers, and the trailers -- none of this feels real. For the first time in 11 years, there is a college football game and it's called EA Sports College Football 25.\n\nAll 128 NCAA Division-1 FBS teams are in the game, and for an unprecedented first, this year's version of college football also features current players. It's a massive grab and statement for EA Orlando, which has been diligently working on the long-awaited successor to NCAA Football 14 since the 2021 announcement.\n\nWith the game launching across PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X on July 19, two of Mashable's biggest CFB fans took cracks at the game to find out if it was worth the wait. The biggest takeaway from our time playing is that CFB 25 gets the vibe of college football just right, even if the entire package could use some work. After all, it's still an EA game.\n\nCollege Football 25 gameplay\n\nSection written by Chance Townsend\n\nPlaying CFB 25 is a smooth and crisp experience. Of course, it's gonna play better than its 11-year-old predecessor, but there's a level of fluidity in here that even puts Madden to shame. This shines within the running game, which is ultra-fun, crisp, and doesn't feel too animation-heavy. Although there were times when hitting the open hole I felt like the animation was sucking me into a tackle. Running is the bread and butter of the CFB 25 experience, and honestly, it shows.\n\nThat doesn't mean the passing game didn't get some love, though. New to this version of the game is \"revamped passing,\" which shows a meter above the receiver's head during a throw. This meter determines the accuracy, power and placement of a pass. Hit the golden spot in the meter, and make the catch, but if you misjudge it, you'll end up putting your receiver in a bad spot. It's very satisfying to use compared to Madden's placement and accuracy, though it lacks the precision of that option. However, if you like Madden's interpretation of passing or love to stick to the classics, both options are available to choose from.\n\nThe passing game in general is harder than in years past. There's a frustrating amount of dropped passes by receivers at the slightest bit on contact, which makes for a troublesome gaming experience -- while probably true to life, its not fun to play with. So if you thought you could spam 4 Verts like you could in NCAA 14 for easy gains, well tough noogies buddy, get ready to learn how to RPO.\n\nSpeaking of the run-pass option, it's busted as hell. If you can't immediately make a decision when passing, you'll get an illegal man downfield penalty 90 percent of the time.\n\nOn top of that, the new two-part kick meter may also cause some yelling. Which, again, in real life, these things are difficult, but it doesn't make for a fun video game experience.\n\nDefense, however, is not fun. On higher difficulties like All-American and Heisman, stopping anything felt impossible. To be fair, the last Frostbite Engine-era football game I played was Madden 18, so maybe I just suck ass, but I don't think Troy should realistically be dropping 35 on the Longhorns.\n\nCollege Football 25 presentation and vibes\n\nSection written by Alex Perry\n\nCollege football holds a special place in my heart, probably unreasonably so. America's second-favorite version of its most popular sport is unlike any other. The games are often sloppy to the point of hilarity, intensely weird things happen all the time, and one time, a guy got so mad about a game that he poisoned historic trees on the opposing team's campus and called into a talk radio show to admit his guilt.\n\nThis colorful menagerie of nonsense, naturally, produces fantastic vibes. Every school has various ancient rituals the players or fans do before, during, and after games. Notre Dame players tap a sign that says \"PLAY LIKE A CHAMPION TODAY\" in the pregame tunnel. Nebraska fans unleash red balloons after the first scoring play of every home game. Everyone, no matter who they're rooting for, turns and waves at a children's hospital that overlooks the stadium during every Iowa home game.\n\nWithout meandering even more, I'll get straight to the point. Pretty much all of those things are present and accounted for in College Football 25. Nearly all that makes college football a compelling TV product, from boisterous marching bands and drumlines to nuclear-powered crowd noise, are represented in the game. The latter point actually affects gameplay, as receiver routes and icons will become misleading or confusing to read while an opposing crowd is bearing down on you. That's not new to football games, per se, but it's still very cool to feel the pressure of driving for a touchdown as the away team at Ohio State.\n\nSure, there are some typical jerky or unnatural-looking animations (as there have been in every 3D football game ever), but on the whole, College Football 25 nails the look of college football, too. Every in-game stadium, from Michigan's Big House to North Texas's DATCU Stadium, is stunningly rendered. Crowds look voluminous and energetic, too.\n\nThe game gets big points from me for also altering the colors and theming of the main menu depending on which school you choose as your favorite team. In particular, I love that every school's main menu screen features a ticket stub to a legendary real-life game from that program's history. Remember the time in 2011 when Iowa State upset Oklahoma State in overtime? No? Well, I do, and so did the developers of this game -- and that's what matters.\n\nThere are really only a couple of minor criticisms I have of College Football 25's presentation. First up is the commentary, which is made up of various big names in the world of college football broadcasting like Chris Fowler, Rece Davis, and Kirk Herbstreit. Those guys are all pretty much fine, if a little flat at times. The play-by-play guys like Fowler and Davis will occasionally throw in school-specific references, which is cute. I enjoyed hearing some \"Rock Chalk Jayhawk\" while playing a game at Kansas, for example.\n\nUnfortunately, the game also includes David Pollack on color commentary. I don't like David Pollack very much, for reasons that are not entirely relevant to this review. I also just find his commentary annoying and inane most of the time. Beyond that, any stadium rituals that involve licensed music are touch-and-go at best. Virginia Tech can potentially lay claim to the greatest pregame intro in all of sports, but since it uses Metallica's \"Enter Sandman,\" it's not accurately presented in this game. Bummer.\n\nStill, you'll occasionally hear \"Sandstorm\" blaring over stadium speakers between plays in any given game, so it still feels enough like college football to me.\n\nCollege Football 25 Dynasty Mode\n\nSection written by Alex Perry\n\nCollege Football 25 has two primary modes that dominate most of the attention outside of online exhibitions and microtransaction trading card nonsense. The first is Dynasty, a returning mode from the NCAA games of eld that casts the player as a made up head coach or coordinator for the school of their choosing.\n\nI have to admit, I was never the biggest Dynasty guy back in the day -- and I still may not be. But the version of the mode that's present in College Football 25 seems to have nearly everything you could want. Your coach or coordinator can have as many or as few responsibilities as you want. If you want to be meticulous about recruiting talent, you can do that. If you want to focus on gameday tactics and actually playing football (which is really more of a fun treat you get to occasionally do in this mode), you can do that, too.\n\nSpeaking of recruiting, that particular side of College Football 25's Dynasty mode is funny. It more or less works the same as it always did, as you have limited resources for player recruiting and the players' decisions are not entirely in your hands. It's been updated for modern times, though, as one of the resource-consuming activities you can do to court a player is to DM him on social media.\n\nYes, there is a button that just says \"DM player\" in the Dynasty menu. I laughed a lot when I saw that.\n\nAside from that, though, Dynasty is impressively flexible and accommodates many different styles of play for something that, from the outside, would seem to be the most hardcore mode in the game. I pretty much only like playing offense in football games, so I made an offensive coordinator and only call offensive plays now. Easy! That's what I like to see. If I'm good enough at it, maybe I'll get a mediocre head coaching job, flame out in three years, and cause an entire community in Tennessee or whatever to hate me for eternity. That's what college football is all about.\n\nCollege Football 25 Road to Glory\n\nSection written by Chance Townsend\n\nGone are the glory days of playing in high school with this year's version of CFB 25. In previous games, players could simulate high school games to garner interest from potential schools and commit to them. However, that feature got cut in favor of a more limited, streamlined Road to Glory (RTG) experience.\n\nInstead, players can pick from one of four options, starting as an elite five-star talent to a lowly two-star underdog. Your decision will determine your player overall, your choice of schools, and your place on that program's depth chart. For example, a five-star will have their top of top-level programs like UT-Austin or Michigan. But a two or three-star will have their pick of fighting for starting spots at lowly programs like Air Force or Eastern Michigan. You can walk on to any school in the game, but you'll be starting from the bench and it's hard to get rise up the depth chart.\n\nI started my RTG at Memphis, which promised my created QB the second-string position. Once the creation and recruitment process is done, you'll be taken to the main hub where you can play or sim that week's game, participate in practice drills, and spend energy points on your weekly agenda. You have the choice to put your energy into academics, leadership skills, recovery, training, or brand building. These each come with pros and cons that affect each other. For example, putting points into brand building will drop your academic bar; training causes increased injury risk; and low leadership skills create a passive loss of coach trust points until you've invested a certain amount of energy into that agenda.\n\nAdditionally, there are fun choose-your-adventure style scenarios that pop up throughout the season. You'll occasionally get messages from your academic advisor, your coaches, teammates, and even classmates that'll put you in scenarios that could increase your brand, GPA, and coach trust, or vice versa. In one instance, a classmate asked me to party the night before a game, and when I said yes, my coach caught me and I lost trust points.\n\nYou can gain a coach's trust through practice and playing games, but if you're sitting on the bench, you'll have a hard time getting points cause the drills you can play are really short and your success depends on how well the AI is at giving you plays you can work with.\n\nLimitation is pretty much the theme of playing RTG. Since you're not really in control, while playing games, you're at the mercy of the AI from everything like playcalling to the actions of your teammates on the field. Playcalling is repetitive and conservative. Going 3 and Out will cause an unskippable cutscene as you fade back into the super sim screen and the AI will only allow you to call hurry up on 4th down during the last few minutes of each half -- when the situation determines that going for it \"makes sense.\"\n\nReceivers drop open balls like they have grease on their hands and handing the ball off to the running back is like watching an AI programmer teach their LLM how to navigate a maze. So when I finally got to start at Memphis in my second season, I started 0-4 before finishing the season with a conference championship and a 7-6 record. That conference championship, by the way, did not have a special trophy presentation. Instead, I got the same victory cutscene that you get after every other game during the regular season.\n\nIf you're surprised my 7-6 Memphis Tigers even made the conference championship, that's because the sim engine is busted. This is partially due to the overall of the teams in the game being so evenly rated despite the huge gaps between teams like Akron and Alabama. Despite going 2-10 in 2023, the Akron Zips are a 73 overall team. Kennesaw State, a team that is about to have its first season in Division 1 Football (D-1 FBS), is a 73 overall team. Mid-level Power 4 schools like Texas Tech, Miami, A&M, Arkansas, Ole Miss, Utah, and Florida State are all within the 85-88 OVR range. Thus, what's been created is a level of college football parity that has never existed in real life. There are no haves and have-nots because even the fake cupcake FCS teams can beat a Power 4 school with ease.\n\nThis creates weird situations that see 6-6 Memphis play 7-6 Rice in the American Athletic Conference (AAC) championship because #4 ranked Tulane dropped its last two conference games to UTSA and Charlotte. In the first season, my alma mater, the University of North Texas, made the 12-team College Football Playoff despite only having three winning seasons since 2010. That season also saw Texas A&M win the National Championship -- a true real immersion breaker because the real-life A&M has yet to make an appearance in the SEC Championship.\n\nUnlike Dynasty, the happenings of the world around you don't have much to do with you since you don't have to deal with things like recruiting and roster management. Plus, historically, RTG has been a rather shallow experience. However, thanks to the addition of the transfer portal, you can change your team at the end of every season to create some interesting scenarios in your career.\n\nCUT and best of the rest\n\nSection written by Chance Townsend\n\nWhat's left to cover in this review is the Ultimate Team mode or CUT (College Ultimate Team). While I've never cared for Ultimate Team in any game, this version of EA's favorite money collector isn't as in your face as its other offerings like EAFC or Madden. We didn't play around much with CUT during our play testing, so our review is limited, however, it must be said that for those new to the Frostbite Engine era of EA sports games, CUT is the perfect place to start.\n\nNot because that's where EA wants you to spend money, but because the offering of solo challenges is an excellent way to get used to the different playbooks and schemes that can be used in other modes like Dynasty. It's the perfect training ground to get a feel of what kind of style you'd want to play for whenever you decide to take the reigns at a bottom-barrel MAC program. Each playbook offers different challenges, like the Air Raid that asks you to use a hurry-up offense and pass for five straight plays.\n\nIs College Football 25 Worth It?\n\nTo keep things brief, if you love college football, this game you're waiting for. As a pure gameplay experience, CFB 25 is both challenging and rewarding in ways that Madden and 2K aren't. However, it's not the game we've waited 11 years for. Dynasty lacks a lot of depth and quality-of-life changes that were present in NCAA 14, alongside a mind-numbingly inane UI and drumline menu songs.\n\nEA Orlando promised fans that this is the college football game they deserve, and considering it has all the trappings of an EA sports game, they weren't lying. But if you can look past that and just focus on what's in the game, you'll have a fun time.", "source": {"uri": "sea.mashable.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mashable SEA"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8232508857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:16:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:16:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:10:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2793756/", "title": "College Football 25 video game revival is bittersweet for fans who kept NCAA Football 14 alive - ExBulletin", "body": "Erik Vallow just couldn't match Isaiah Simmons' 79 speed rating.\n\nVallow, 19, was in his first year at Indiana in 2019, trying to keep the spark of his favorite video game alive. But the game was NCAA Football 14, and the rosters were long outdated.\n\nSo like millions of other college football junkies, Vallow went online and downloaded an updated roster file compiled by an anonymous fan on a Discord server. That file contained the aforementioned Simmons discrepancy. Random ratings like that are killing Vallow. He had to do something about it.\n\nThat one jumped out at me, and I thought, what if I could figure out a way to do this other than manually on an Xbox, Vallow said. And then fast forward to college, freshman year my first class was an introduction to Excel, and I thought, oh my God, this is the way. This is how I would do it.\n\nVallow took his rudimentary Excel skills and built player generation models to formulate player ratings. He said Simmons' speed was just one of many minor issues he had with fan-generated roster files. It spurred Vallow on a hobby that turned into an obsession that ended with a job.\n\nNow 24, he's parlayed his passion for creating updated NCAA 14 roster files into a part-time job at EA Sports, where he applies his custom-built ranking algorithms as part of the team that builds the roster for College Football 25, the first college football video game released in 11 years.\n\nWhen NCAA Football went down, I thought we were never going to get the game back. I thought that was it, said Kofi Yeboah, a content creator at Secret base who makes gaming videos. It was like, keep your Xbox 360, keep your PS3, because that's the only way you can play.\n\nVallow made it his unpaid job to keep NCAA 14 as current as possible, and he was determined to be methodical with his evaluations. He didn't want to base complex receiver evaluations on two-dimensional stats like receptions and yards. He didn't want to gloss over the complexities of offensive and defensive lineman skills. What he wanted was tangible data.\n\nThen came Pro Football Focus. Around 2020, PFF, a sports analytics company that uses a rating system to evaluate every player on every play in a football game, began sharing its college football data publicly with its subscribers.\n\nVallow, then a sophomore majoring in finance and business analytics with hopes of becoming an investment banker, dove into the data. Now he had real numbers to back up his video game ratings. Some extra time from living at home due to the COVID-19 pandemic helped, too.\n\nThe main thing I always wanted was that I wanted to have some kind of data backup for every metric, he said. So if someone said, Hey, why is so-and-so using this route compared to that? Well, everything always went back to data.\n\nVallow later realized that high school athletic statistics and off-season training could provide him with even more information for assessing physical attributes.\n\nWhen he started sharing his updated rosters publicly, people were shocked by the details of players' physical attributes, even as some opponents felt their schools and favorite players were being underrated. Vallow had learned to trust his data.\n\nThere were some guys from MAC schools who were like, Hey, so and so (isn't rated well) and I'm just going to say sorry and do it in the next update, he said, laughing. Kansas was one where I just got beat up, and I was like, I'm going to try this with thousands of players!\n\nAfter further refining his formulas and learning how to better interpret his data, Vallow proved that his rating system was scalable to thousands of players.\n\nWhen EA Sports announced that a college football game would actually be coming back, he reached out to an employee on LinkedIn and offered to share all the work he had done. He was soon hired as an independent contractor to work with their roster team.\n\nI called them and said, 'Hey, I can now put together Alabama's entire recruiting class right now based on the data that I have, by inputting it and calculating it.' And I think they were like, 'Oh, this is really valuable.'\n\nOperation Sports sees thousands of users flock to hundreds of video game forum threads every day. The site's college football community is one of its most visited destinations, and it's a place where real relationships have been formed over the years.\n\nAs for the community itself, it's positive. There are a lot of people who are friends and then they join Discords together, so there's still a lot of that stuff going on, said Chase Becotte, senior editor of Operation Sports, comparing his site's user base to other forums.\n\nWith Reddit, it's a more negative dogpile, and that goes for both users and topics. We can still be negative on topics, but this community is great. I think it's a good balance overall.\n\nWhile it's not uncommon for a video game to have a loyal fanbase, it's much more common for communities to hate the games themselves.\n\nBut in the decade-plus that the college football community went without a new game, something different happened to the people who kept NCAA 14 alive. That community thrived on both the nostalgia of NCAA 14 feeling like the series' final game and the fact that it was a genuinely well-made title, Becotte said.\n\nIt's pretty awesome, Vallow said. From the outside, if someone said to me, Me and all my friends are talking online about this 10-year-old video game, I'd be like, You guys are kind of losers. But then I'm like, Wait a minute, that's me.\n\nRoster updaters like Vallow had hundreds of fans leave feedback on reviews. Streamers like Yeboah had thousands of YouTube viewers watching him rebuild East Carolina in Dynasty mode.\n\nHere it's your sandbox and you share your sandcastle creations with your friends, and that's cool, Yeboah said.\n\nNow that the golden age of College Football 25 has arrived, complete with real player names, thanks to NIL, what happens to those sandcastles?\n\nBecotte called it bittersweet. Yeboah said he'll have a hard time letting NCAA 14 go for good.\n\nYou're going to make me cry, Mark, Vallow said. I don't know what I'm going to be like.\n\nIn video games, an 11-year gap is like a 110-year technological leap in another industry. But for the gaming generation of yesteryear, Becotte and Vallow are confident that EA Sports has spent the last decade listening to its fans and giving its community the features they've been asking for.\n\nAnd if College Football 25 can't match the legacy of NCAA 14? Well, the old game isn't far behind.\n\nThe community has kept the game alive for as long as it needed to be, Yeboah said, and even when College Football 25 comes out, I think there will still be a lot of people playing NCAA 14 because the game is that good.\n\nVallow was 13 years old when NCAA 14 came out. His younger brother was around 13 when Vallow was home during COVID-19 and making his roster updates. Now their youngest brother is 13 years old with College Football 25 coming out.\n\nHe says he has no idea whether his younger brothers will appreciate the new game as much as he has over the past decade, but Vallow is hopeful that the spirit of NCAA 14 will live on, as fans have had the chance to influence the next generation of college football games.\n\nWhen he first joined EA Sports, he was shocked to discover that fans like himself were putting together College Football 25.\n\nObviously I'm going to miss that game, but because you play it so much, there's a little bit of you that thinks, maybe if this, this, this, and this were different, and that's the great thing that EA did. They listened and it looks like it was too good to be true, Vallow said.\n\nI thought, You guys really listened to the things that people wanted? And they said, Yeah, we goods these people.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Nielsen Media Research"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Excel", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Microsoft Excel"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Collegiate Athletic Association"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_football", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "College football"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game", {"uri": "2024-07-426225099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "16:11:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T16:11:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T16:05:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://gamerant.com/ea-sports-college-football-25-road-to-glory-how-to-get-earn-skill-points/", "title": "College Football 25: Road To Glory - How To Get Skill Points", "body": "Football fans have plenty to be excited about, as they're not only getting a new Madden game this year, but can also get their hands on the first college football gaming experience in over a decade. In EA Sports College Football 25, players can carve their own destiny as a rising star on the competitive collegiate football stage.\n\nThose who are partaking in their own player journey in Road To Glory mode will need to balance studies, training, sponsorship opportunities, and a social life, as they try to elevate their team and realize their national championship dreams. A big part of achieving this requires knowledge of how to get Skill Points in College Football 25, as their player will need to continue to improve in order to beat the best teams in college football.\n\nRelated\n\nEA Sports College Football 25 Burning Questions\n\nThe following guide will aim to answer all of the most frequently asked questions about EA Sports College Football 25.\n\nWhat Are Skill Points in Road To Glory?\n\nPlayer ratings are a staple in any major sports game, from UFC and NBA to NFL and NHL, and will be the same case in Madden 25, and is no different in EA Sports College Football, as every player is given a rating that reflects their skills. In Road To Glory mode, you will pick your starting rating and work towards improving it, alongside building your coach's trust, which is where Skill Points come into play.\n\nSkill Points are somewhat of a currency that players can earn and spend to upgrade their athlete in different facets of their game. These facets will depend on the position you are playing, but will include attributes such as elusiveness, strength, and accuracy. The higher the skill level, the more Skill Points you will need to spend to upgrade.\n\nHow To Get Skill Points in Road To Glory\n\nAs the name might suggest, Skill Points are best acquired by showcasing your skills in the position you play in, whether that be Quarterback, Running Back, Tight End, or Wide Receiver. There are two primary ways that Skill Points can be acquired:\n\nBy spending Energy on Training each week. This can be done in the Weekly Agenda section of the Road To Glory hub. It's worth noting, however, that any points you spend on training can't be used for other areas that are not as easily accessible in-game, such as Endorsements or Leadership. By completing milestones during games. These milestones include reaching another first down, performing successful throws or catches, and scoring touchdowns. Each positive feat you achieve in a game will contribute to your total XP, which you will need to earn to get Skill Points.\n\nNaturally, the journey that you choose in Road To Glory mode will determine how accessible these opportunities are. You will find that progression as an Underdog is far slower, as you are reliant on the Weekly Agenda Training more, since you are given little to no opportunities to showcase your skills on the field. Elite, on the other hand, will have you leveling up much faster, as you'll likely be making the starting squad within the first couple of weeks, if not immediately.\n\nEA Sports College Football {"uri": "8233815389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:04:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:04:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:04:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/technology/gaming/2024/07/19/669a70ba268e3eb6138b4593.html", "title": "College Football 25 Deluxe vs Standard: What's the difference between both editions and which one you should get?", "body": "Gaming. The new EA Sports College Football 25 is here and these are the best memes to prove it\n\nThe College Football series of video games, by EA Sports, simulates American college football in a realistic gameplay with real college players and it comes in different editions offering different benefits so what are the variances, and which is right for you?\n\nInitially released as Bill Walsh College Football in 1993, the series evolved into NCAA Football, running annually until 2013, offering an immersive experience of collegiate football.\n\nThe series was highly popular, known for its Dynasty and Road to Glory modes but due to licensing issues and controversies over player likenesses, the series was discontinued after NCAA Football 14.\n\nHowever, EA Sports revived the series under the name EA Sports College Football in 2021 and announced the first release of the second era in summer 2023 and now the game is back to its popular self, offering an alternative to those frustrated with Madden.\n\nThe Standard Edition includes the game, priced at $69.99 on the PS Store and Xbox Store for digital copies, whilst anyone preordering can also pick up an Alma Mater Ultimate Team Pack, a Cover Athlete Ultimate Team Pack and a Return to Glory Ultimate Team Uniform Item.\n\nIf you are a competitive gamer who is seeking to be the best you can possibly be then the benefits are clear with the Deluxe Edition, offering bonuses for an extra price of $30.\n\nNot only will you gain more time to learn the game, but you will also be handed some pretty sweet players and credit out of the gate to boost your team up and immediately begin to throw down a challenge to players worldwide.\n\nBut if you are interested in casually playing the game and you're not really that bothered about how well you do, or you're new to the series, then the Standard Edition is right for you. Save the $30, learn the game or have fun and switch it off when it's too frustrating.\n\nFirst out of the gate is an earlier release date giving you an extra three days to learn the game and gain an advantage over your friends. The Deluxe Edition releases on July 16 whilst those on the Standard Edition will need to wait until July 19.\n\nFor the price of $99.99, Deluxe Edition buyers will gain an extra three days of playing time as well as 4600 College Football Points, an Alma Mater Ultimate Team Pack a Cover Athlete Ultimate Team Pack and Bring Glory Home Ultimate Team Uniform Item.\n\nAdditionally, on the PS5 and Xbox {"uri": "8231721788", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "12:05:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T12:05:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T12:04:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/college-football/2024/7/18/24200483/college-football-25-review-ps5-xbox-best-sports-games-ever", "title": "'College Football 25' delivers on all its promises to become one of the best football games of all-time", "body": "There are few video games met with more anticipation than College Football 25. Over a decade of yearning met its catharsis with the game's release this week -- which leaves the only burning question: Is it all worth it? Is EA Sports' return to college football the game fans deserve, or have fears of a phoned-in, re-skinned version of Madden been realized?\n\nIt's unfair to keep that answer a secret any longer, so let's go ahead and say it. Not only is College Football 25 the love letter to the sport that fans have been waiting for, but it's also one of the greatest football games ever released. That statement comes with a weight of experiencing dating back to Madden 95, through NFL 2K5, and even the oft-forgotten NFL Quarterback Club series. Yes, this is the game you wanted -- and yes, it's spectacular.\n\nThere are myriad differences between College Football 25 and Madden, but on its most superficial level everything just feels different, more special, and more considered. It's clear that the development team behind the game is deeply aware of the importance of atmosphere and individuality, and every single team is just dripping in it.\n\nNo two games feel the same when playing the home team. Each school's pre-game traditions, fight songs, and in-stadium atmosphere have been recreated to such a level that there are times it doesn't even feel like the same game. There's a chasm of difference between playing at home as a struggling, low-prestige team that has difficulty filling the stands -- and fever-pitch Saturday night rivalry game in Ann Arbor.\n\nIn addition to obvious differences like fan density and volume, there are dozens of small pieces of nuance you notice over time. Fans in the stands of a Georgia game, for instance, are more likely to have painted faces, hold signs, even paint multi-fan messages on their stomachs -- while a more buttoned-up football school like North Carolina has a tendency to have fans that skew older, predominantly wearing polos and khakis.\n\nThis extends to music on stadiums PAs as well. The location of the school, paired with the area's demographics play a role in what you'll hear on game day. LSU pipes a lot of hip hop into its stadium. West Virginia plays predominantly classic rock. If you hear it on game day there's a good chance you'll hear it in College Football 25.\n\nIt's tough to quantify exactly what all these differences do to improve the experience, but in totality it all just feels special. Even with schools I don't personally know much about, the presentation heightens the experience. During my dynasty I was playing at Old Dominion, only to be met with a shot of the school's color guard in full military uniform. Sure enough it's a tradition at football games, and if something like that has been created for Old Dominion, you can extrapolate what has been done for larger, more popular schools.\n\nNobody is left behind in College Football 25. If you're a school that has been included you're going to get a completely individualized atmosphere and feel. No generic stadiums. No half-assed creations. Everything is bespoke, and beautiful.\n\nAre there similarities to the on-field actions of Madden? Yes, but don't for a second think this is a one-for-one copy. While there is shared DNA between some animations, plays, and schemes, that's about as far as the comparisons go.\n\nPlaying College Football 25 at its heart is a faster-paced, higher scoring football game than most people are accustomed to. Big plays happen with regularity, especially when there's a distinct talent mismatch between teams. Part of what makes this system work so well is the imperfection, something I lauded about the leaps Madden 25 made last year.\n\nMissed blocks, failed assignments, blown coverage and botched tackles are far more prevalent in college ball than its pro cousin, and that all makes for unique experiences. There are no go-to plays that always work. Conversely there are plays that NEVER work in Madden, but are actually effective in College Football 25. When was the last time you saw a draw play go for 10+ yards, or a counter run actually work? Both do in this game, and it completely revolutionizes how running the ball feels.\n\nIf you're a person who loves the ground game, then this game is a godsend. Carrying the rock is essential to a good offense in College Football 25, and with all the imperfections in play there's a need to get solid, reliable yards through the running game. Blocking has been vastly overhauled where across dozens of games I've yet to see a missed block or assignment that makes zero sense, with wide receivers and tight ends doing their part to seal the edges or get out ahead and block downfield -- rather than just stop and watch the play as we've become accustomed to.\n\nThis has a knock on effect where play action passing works better, trick plays are more impactful, and if you've established the run you will see it affect the rest of your play calling. Just like we see in the real game.\n\nPassing has never been more exciting, or nerve-wracking. A critical 3rd-and-7 is no longer met with a rote, memorized play that can always pick up 10. If your No. 1 receiver isn't a bonafide star player they can, and will run their route incorrectly, make a slow cut, or get jammed to the point their out of the play. It doesn't happen with enough regularity to become a frustration, it's just a known element of the game you need to scheme and work around to achieve success.\n\nThere's never a shortage of things to do in College Football 25. In fact, turning it on is a constant case of decision paralysis. Do I want to experience a big rivalry game of a team I haven't played? Keep working on my Dynasty, where the be recruiting decision is coming down to the wire for that dual-threat QB I've invested so much time in? What about my power running back in Road to Glory? Doesn't anyone care about my anthropomorphized version of Bluey's dad from the hit Disney kids show Bluey?\n\nBandit Heeler is currently RB2 for Washington. Just thought I'd let you know.\n\nWhat makes the experience of College Football 25 so great is the constant shifts in experience you're able to have. This isn't a case of simply jumping between variations of the same thing, but very unique experiences that have as much to do with what you do off the field, than on it.\n\nDynasty is a fully-realized college football seasonal experience. Recruiting is the heart of the non-football activity, and once you understand its systems it's incredibly engaging. Every recruit has a chart of things that are important to them ranging from playing time, to personal brand, and distance to their home -- all of which play a role in how you recruit. A 1.5 star prestige school can't offer brand, so you'll need to focus on other areas to recruit, and from there it's almost a turn-based RPG of selecting the right moves at the right time to enter a recruit's Top 8, then Top 5, and hopefully get a commitment.\n\nThese moves are all budgeted with hours, and using them wisely is a really fun puzzle to put together. You can up the pressure by having a recruit visit on the weekend of a tough game, knowing that a win or loss on the field won't just effect standings, but your ability to land your target.\n\nThat same sort of budgeting and RPG experience is present in Road to Glory, which serves as the \"be a pro\" mode for the game. Here you'll need to balance being a college athlete with keeping your grades up, socializing, building your brand, and training for the field -- and it's remarkably difficult to hit all those notes while earning coach trust and playing time as a result.\n\nThe differences between Dynasty and Road to Glory as so significant that they feel like different games, and that's a great thing that keeps the came constantly fresh. The second you get frustrated with one, jump on over and work on something else. It creates a brilliant package that's impossible to put down.\n\nCollege Football 25 is so far beyond a debut product it's astonishing. If this is the launching off point for more then the future is in good hands. The game delivers on giving the sights, sounds, and feel of the sport in a way that's addictive beyond all measure.\n\nMore than anything else, College Football 25 delivers on bringing fun back to football. It's the biggest leap we've seen in football gaming in years -- maybe even ever, and that makes it a must-own for anyone with even a passing interest in college football.\n\nNow, if you'll excuse me I need to try and have Bandit Heeler become the featured back on Washington's playoff team.", "source": {"uri": "sbnation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SB Nation"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dmoz/Games", "label": "dmoz/Games", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Play-By-Mail", "label": "dmoz/Games/Play-By-Mail", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Board_Games/Historical", "label": "https://cdn.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/7rmB1JV98bHn9fG6Ylv89CnftPs=/0x0:1454x727/fit-in/1200x600/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_asset/file/25535148/lsu.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8231435768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "09:16:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T09:16:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T09:14:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5644072/2024/07/18/ncaa-football-14-rosters-college-football-25/", "title": "NCAA Football 14 diehards spent hundreds of hours updating rosters. How do they feel now?", "body": "Erik Vallow just couldn't handle Isaiah Simmons' speed rating being a 79.\n\nThe 19-year-old Vallow was in his freshman year at Indiana in 2019, trying to keep the spark of his favorite video game alive. But the game was NCAA Football 14, and the rosters were long outdated.\n\nSo like millions of other college football junkies, Vallow went online and downloaded an updated roster file, put together by an anonymous fan on a Discord server. That file contained the aforementioned Simmons discrepancy. Haphazard ratings like that ground Vallow's gears. He had to do something about it.\n\n\"That one stuck out to me, and I was like, 'If only I knew any way to do this other than manually on an Xbox,'\" Vallow said. \"And then flash forward to college, in freshman year my first class was an intro to Excel class, and I was like, 'Oh my God, this is the way. This is how I would do it.'\"\n\nVallow went to work with his rudimentary Excel skills and built out player generation models to determine player ratings formulaically. He said Simmons' speed was just one of many small things he took issue with in fan-made roster files. It spurred Vallow into a hobby that became an obsession and ended with a job.\n\nNow 24, he parlayed a passion project of creating updated NCAA 14 roster files into a part-time job with EA Sports, where he applies his custom-made rating algorithms as a member of the roster creation team for College Football 25 -- the first college football video game released in 11 years.\n\n\"When NCAA Football stopped, I thought we were never getting the game back. I thought that was it,\" said Kofi Yeboah, a content creator with Secret Base who makes gaming videos. \"It was like keep your Xbox 360, keep your PS3, because that's the only way you'll be able to play.\"\n\nVallow made it his unpaid job to keep NCAA 14 as updated as possible, and he was determined to be methodical with his ratings. He didn't want to base complex receiver ratings off two-dimensional statistics like receptions and yards. He didn't want to gloss over the intricacies of offensive and defensive lineman skill sets. What he wanted was tangible data.\n\nThen came Pro Football Focus. Around 2020, PFF -- a sports analytics company that uses a grading system to evaluate every player on every play during a football game -- started sharing its college football data publicly with its subscribers.\n\nVallow, who was then in his sophomore year and majoring in finance and business analytics with hopes of becoming an investment banker, dived into the data. Now he had real-life numbers to back up his video-game ratings. Some extra time from living back at home due to the COVID-19 pandemic helped too.\n\n\"My biggest thing I always wanted was for every stat, I wanted some sort of data backup for it,\" he said. \"So if someone asked, 'Hey, why is so-and-so's route running this number compared to that?' Well, everything was always going back to data.\"\n\nVallow later realized track and field statistics from a player's high school and offseason training can give him even more information for rating physical traits.\n\nWhen he started sharing his updated rosters publicly, people were shocked by the detail of the players' physical attributes, even if there were naysayers who felt their school and favorite players were underrated. Vallow had learned to lean on his data.\n\n\"There'd be some guys from some MAC schools saying, 'Hey, so and so (isn't rated right)' and I'd just say sorry and get to it in the next update,\" he said with a laugh. \"Kansas was one where I just got ripped, and I was like 'I'm trying -- this is thousands of players!'\"\n\nAfter continuing to fine-tune his formulas while learning how to better interpret his data, Vallow proved his rating system was successfully scalable for thousands of players.\n\nWhen EA Sports announced that a college football game was truly coming back, he reached out to an employee on LinkedIn and offered to share all the work he put together. He was soon hired as an independent contractor to work with their roster team.\n\n\"I got on a call and showed them, 'Hey I could generate Alabama's whole recruiting class right now just based on the data I have, just input and calculate,'\" he said, \"and I think they were like, 'Oh, this is actually valuable.'\"\n\nAt Operation Sports, thousands of users flock to hundreds of video game forum threads on a daily basis. The site's college football community is among its most frequented destinations, and it's a place where genuine relationships have formed over the years.\n\n\"In terms of the community itself, that's a positive. There's a lot of people who are friends and then they join Discords together as well, so there's a lot of that stuff that's still happening,\" said Chase Becotte, senior editor of Operation Sports, comparing the users on his site to other forums.\n\n\"With Reddit, it is a more negative dogpile, and that's on users as well as topics. We can still get negative about topics, but this community rules. I think it's a good balance overall.\"\n\nWhile it's not rare for a video game to have a devoted fan base, it's far more common for communities to be devoted to hating the games themselves.\n\nBut in the decade-plus of the college football community going without a new game, something different happened with the people who kept NCAA 14 alive. That community thrived on both the nostalgia of NCAA 14 seeming like the last game of the series and also that it was a really well-made title, Becotte said.\n\n\"It's pretty awesome,\" Vallow said. \"From the outside, if someone was telling me, 'Me and all my friends talk online about this 10-year-old video game,' I'd be like, 'You guys are kind of losers.' But then I'm like, 'Wait a second, that's me.'\"\n\nRoster updaters like Vallow had hundreds of fans giving feedback on ratings. Streamers like Yeboah have thousands of YouTube viewers watching him rebuild East Carolina in Dynasty mode.\n\n\"Here, it's your sandbox and you're sharing sandcastle creations with your friends, and it's dope,\" Yeboah said.\n\nSo what happens to those sandcastles now that the high tide of College Football 25 is rolling in -- complete with real players' names, thanks to NIL?\n\nBecotte called it bittersweet. Yeboah said he'll have a hard time putting NCAA 14 away for good.\n\n\"You're gonna make me cry, Mark,\" Vallow said. \"I don't know what I'm gonna be like.\"\n\nIn video games, an 11-year gap is like a 110-year technological leap in another industry. But for the gaming generation of yesteryear, Becotte and Vallow are confident that EA Sports has listened to its fan base over the past decade and are giving its community the features they've clamored for.\n\nAnd if College Football 25 doesn't live up to the legacy of NCAA 14? The old game won't be far away.\n\n\"The community kept the game alive for as long as it needed to be,\" Yeboah said, \"and even when College Football 25 comes out, I feel like there's still going to be a bunch of people that play NCAA 14 because that's just how good the game is.\"\n\nVallow was 13 years old when NCAA 14 was released. His younger brother was around 13 years old when Vallow was back home during COVID-19 making his roster updates. Now their youngest brother is 13 years old with College Football 25 coming out.\n\nHe said he has no idea if his younger brothers will appreciate the new game like he has for the past decade, but Vallow cherishes that the spirit of NCAA 14 will live on because fans have gotten to influence the next generation of college football games.\n\nWhen he first started working with EA Sports, he was shocked to find fans like himself were the ones putting College Football 25 together.\n\n\"Obviously I'm going to miss that game, but also like you play it so much, there's a little bit of you that thinks, 'Maybe if this, this, this and this were different,' and that's the awesome thing that EA did. They listened and it seems like it was too good to be true,\" Vallow said.\n\n\"I was like, 'You guys were actually listening to the things people wanted?' And they were like, 'Yeah, we were those people.'\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mark_puleo@nytimes.com", "name": "Mark {"uri": "8233840529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:24:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:24:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:23:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2794827/", "title": "UCF Player Ratings, Team Ratings in EA College Football 25 - ExBulletin", "body": "After an 11-year wait, UCF football fans can finally play as the Knights with the release of College Football 25.\n\nThe last time EA Sports released a college football video game was in 2013 with NCAA Football 14. Back then, gamers couldn't play as Blake Bortles; instead, QB #5 was UCF's center. With the NIL rules in place, player names and likenesses have appeared in-game for the first time, meaning UCF fans can hit the digital field with RJ Harvey, KJ Jefferson, and the rest of the Knights.\n\nIsn't that enough? How about a virtual rocket launch over the Bounce House:\n\nHere's the full roster for UCF in College Football 25, including each player's rating and a look at UCF's ratings overall:\n\nThe game is available now for those who pre-ordered it, but the official release date is Friday, July 19.\n\nThe game will not be released on PC. It will only be available on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S. Previous-gen consoles, PS4 and Xbox One, will not be able to play College Football 25.\n\nThe Standard Edition of the game costs $69.99. The Deluxe Edition costs $99.99. {"uri": "8232763029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:27:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:27:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:26:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/ncaa-football/news/ecu-james-moore-real-player-college-football-25-ea-sports/5bc45c23c2073afe9bc1a71a", "title": "Is ECU's James Moore real? What to know about the lowest-rated player in College Football 25", "body": "EA Sports College Football 25 has all the fan-favorite players, from Shedeur Sanders and Travis Hunter to Arch Manning and ... James Moore?\n\nNever heard of Moore before? That's understandable. He's a fourth-string freshman quarterback on East Carolina's roster in the new college football video game.\n\nThe Pirates' football team isn't very popular to begin with, but fans of even the most well-known programs likely don't know their fourth-string quarterback by name.\n\nMoore has a 12 overall rating in College Football 25, which leaves some players wondering if he's even a real person. The Sporting News answers the question.\n\nMORE: What are the best pipelines in EA Sports College Football 25?\n\nMoore is not a real person -- or at least not a real player on the ECU football roster. It seemed unlikely when users discovered the player, since he's only a 12 overall, but it's now confirmed.\n\nIt's likely that Moore is a random-generated character that EA Sports used to fill a roster spot. This is very common in sports video games, as some players and coaches opt out of the licensing agreement.\n\nMORE: Who is the top rated player in EA Sports College Football 25?\n\nIt's most common with historic teams featured in video games, since leagues typically have an agreement for all players to be included in games. For example, Charles Barkley isn't included in NBA 2K, so the game replaces him with a computer-generated player.\n\nBill Belichick also infamously is left out of the Madden series and is replaced with a generic head coach.\n\nThe generic players are typically lower overall and not in the main rotation or lineup for teams. Still, a 12 overall is absurdly low.\n\nEast Carolina has three quarterbacks on its 2024 roster, and Moore isn't one of them. There isn't a Moore -- or a James, for that matter -- on the Pirates' roster for the 2024 season. {"uri": "8232896128", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "05:37:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T05:37:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T05:36:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2794250/", "title": "EA Sports 'College Football 25' Fans Cheer for Game's Return - ExBulletin", "body": "EA Sports \"College Football 25,\" which is set to be released on Friday, is set to be the most long awaited sports video game of all time.\n\nIn the 2000s it was ranked among the most popular games ever sold. But when new versions were discontinued in 2013 due to a nasty stalemate in legal battles, fans were devastated.\n\nNow, more than ten years later, true fans are happy about its return.\n\n\"When the clock struck midnight on the new year, all I could think was it was finally coming back,\" 25-year-old diehard fan Richard Clemens of Norwalk, Connecticut, told The Post.\n\nHe added that besides being engaged, reprising the college gridiron franchise, a franchise that ran for 21 years before being shut down, is \"the highlight of my year.\"\n\nThe beloved game went belly up 11 years ago when the NCAA has terminated its brand licensing contract and also EA Sports and Collegiate Licensing Company facing paying a $40 million settlement for improper use of the names and likenesses of student-athletes.\n\nA friend of Clemens, Eric Kosh, 26, called it \"hugely disappointing\" that he himself could no longer play an American football video game as a student.\n\n\"It was horrible. We would have tournaments in our dorm all the time,\" Kosh told The Post, adding that he's kept his now-obsolete PlayStation 3 console to continue scoring with the old games ever since.\n\nBut in 2021, the NCAA changed its name, image and likeness (NIL) rights rules, allowing student-athletes to profit from the use of their brand, finally paving the way for new games.\n\n\"The reaction from the fans was like everyone in America won the lottery at the same time,\" Clemens said.\n\nThe manufacturer certainly scored a touchdown: the game's $70 pre-sale with three days of early access for $90 grossed a whopping $70 million during its first recent sneak-peek day, reported Barstool Sports.\n\nThe college-level game, with 134 universities to choose from, always competed with its professional football brethren, the hugely popular series \"John Madden Football\" and \"Madden NFL,\" which offered only 32 average teams.\n\n\"You absolutely can't compare the two. 'College Football' blows 'Madden' out of the water,\" 24-year-old avid player Anthony Pantino of Bethpage, New York, told The Post.\n\nLike Kosh, he fired up his old-school Xbox 360 to play old versions of his favorite games.\n\nThe game even allows players to coach and \"build a college football dynasty from the ground up,\" an intricate aspect that appealed to Pantino since he first fell in love with the game in 2007.\n\n\"The goal is to be better than Nick Saban,\" he said proudly of the legendary Alabama coach who retired earlier this year.\n\nPantino admitted he could spend an entire weekend putting together his virtual football schedule for the long-awaited return of the cutting-edge game.\n\n\"Madden doesn't give you that kind of depth,\" he said, adding that \"College Football\" gives a player \"a real sense of accomplishment.\"\n\nFor other diehards like Kosh, this game is no child's play either. He spent weeks compiling a multi-page document on tactics and tweaks that make the game even more realistically challenging.\n\n\"This is the real deal. We've been waiting over 10 years to get back to it, and I'm not wasting any time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're all glued to our TVs on Friday. If you thought the summer of 'Barbie' was huge, just wait.\"", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
